description:
San Francisco has a lot of public staircases where streets belong.  Mostly because the streets would be steeper than Filbert if they were built.  The result is a plethora of places to get your lungs and legs in shape.  And of these, the Lyon Street Steps are the most scenic.

Whether you start at the top on Broadway close to the Getty compound, or at the bottom on Green near the house that was portrayed as the prep school in "The Princess Diaries", you'll get a good workout in only two blocks.  Luke L counted them, there's either 288 or 332 steps, roughly double the amount on the 16th Avenue set.  Be careful;  if you trip going up, you'll get a damaged knee, and if you trip going down, you'll get a concussion.

I've been here several times, and I've always seen people working out here.  And no wonder:  mansions on the east side, a jaw-dropping view on the north side, and beautiful landscaping.  Hidden away from the street is one of the hearts that was left in San Francisco.  And to clarify Korina Y's comment, there are not 40 million-dollar homes here, these homes sell for $40 million.

The Lyon Street Steps are good for locals and tourists alike.  Enjoy.
author: Ron L.

description:
Super nice viewpoint, just a very scenic place. It's a good place for photos but it's also difficult because a lot of people will probably be around. Regardless, it's nice to be there and look around and take everything in. 

There is a long staircase so it's something to note for those that aren't able to walk stairs.

The green sidelines next to the staircase help make the staircase more elegant. 

There's also one of those famous San Francisco hearts at the bottom of the stairs.

I would recommend a quick drop by to this location. You can then continue on to the Palace of Fine Arts and/or Presidio as they are in walking distance.
author: Karishma M.

description:
Lyon Street Steps one of the more famous public stairways in San Francisco. There are a total of 332 steps (or 288 steps depending on where you count these steps) and they cover about two entire blocks (from Broadway [top of the steps] to Green St. [bottom of the steps]). Our group used a ridesharing app and the driver dropped us off on top of the steps. The view was simply marvelous - you can see the Palace of Fine Arts, the "Billionaires" Row (including Senator Dianne Feinstein's house which is right next to a heart sculpture), a heart sculpture (one of the "Hearts in San Francisco" sculptures scattered across the city), beautiful zen-like gardens, and the San Francisco Bay. If you are a fan of the Princess Diaries, Grove High School is located at the bottom of the steps (or dead end of Green Street).

A lot of people come here for stair workout, but it is also a must-visit instagrammable tourist spot in SF.
author: Luke L.

description:
First time here on a weekend morning.

This place is incredibly beautiful! Many runners taking advantage of the stairs to work out, as well as families taking their kids to hang out. 

Overall it's a very friendly and cozy enviornment. 

The steps oversees the ocean and the buildings of the city. 
The heart-shaped landmark is a great photography spot. 

I was able to find parking easily near the top of the steps. The classy tour cable cars also make a stop there. 

My Google map took me to the top of the steps, instead of the bottom. (If you're not feelin' the climb then that's an alternative.)
author: Jess W.

description:
Did you know there's a great free "gym" in one of the most scenic, beautiful and wealthy areas in SF? Zero initiation fees, zero monthly dues, no contract, and open 24 hours.  OK, so it's not technically a gym, but you'll definitely get in a great work out here!

In an attempt to get outdoors in between the rain, I headed directly to the Lyon Steps. I like to start at Filbert and Lyon, go up and down a couple of times, and then walk along Broadway (aka Billionaires' Row).

On a busy weekend, you'll find lots of healthy, super fit folks bobbing up and down the steps with their headphones on. Even if you don't do a work out here, come for the views, take your out of town friends here, or just come to sneak in a few minutes of zen. It's truly one of my most favorite spots in all of SF!

P.S. And tell Diane I said hello...
author: Lori N.

description:
If you live in the city or if you're visiting the city, you must check these steps out. Really random because they're just steps after all...right? 

I love it though because it's something outside of the city...while still actually being in the city. Here you can see people from all over the world converge...on steps...with an incredible view. 

You can see people taking in the views or you can see group yoga classes. You can see families doing a workout circuit running up and down the steps or even see a dog walker with 10 dogs (seriously, I just saw this yesterday). 

Take in the views but be sure to take a walk up and down the steps! It'll be your workout for the day. T

It's definitely a hike up the steps. There's a lot and they're steep so just something to keep in mind as you look to walk them.
author: Matt M.

description:
I came to Lyon Street Steps for the view, not the hike. I think I got a good enough working out walking up the SF hills to get there. 

The area around and it is truly beautiful. One of those places with an iconic SF view of the houses, geography, ocean and city all in one. 
There were a lot of people here doing yoga, running the steps and hanging out with their dogs. It's clearly a hot destination for locals and visitors alike. 

I wish I had more time to spend here to explore a bit more but we were in a hurry. You should definitely check out Lyon Street Steps.
author: Aaron B.

description: Surrounded by 40 million dollar homes. Lots of well known people live in this affluent neighborhood of San Francisco. Gorgeous view of the bay and the palace of fine arts.  Some locals running up and down the stairs. One of the "heart " sculpture is here. There are 130 of those heart sculptures all over the city. Nice to take a walk in this neighborhood looking at the architecture of 30 - 40 million dollar mansions. Most residents are gone this time of the year , on vacation or staying at their other homes. Everyone returns in August . Parking spot might be hard to find then.
author: Korina Y.

description:
Heck yeah!  The view at the top of these steps is awesome.  Also, the steps provide infrastructure to a nice workout.  There's a reason why outdoor bootcamps and individual fitness buffs flock here.  If you have to burn calories, you deserve a view!  

I like to enter the Presidio from the top of these steps.  Tip:  if you want a view with fewer tourist in your photo, take a pic from the inside of the Presidio, just west of the top of the stairs.
author: Andrea H.

description:
Very nice view!! 
I see a lot of people doing there photo shoots (great place for graduation photos). It's hard to find parking as it is in a residential area. But when you are taking photos, please be mindful for the locals. There was an old guy running, and people did not move for him. I understand you guys want a nice photo, but people do use this step to go up and down Lyon street. 

Other than that, enjoy the view of the bay and the Marina district!
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
Need a workout??    This is the place to get some cardio in.   

PARK on Lyon St and Green TO GET THE FULL EXPERIENCE because the stairs are cut in half by a street PLUS it gets more impressive as you walk up.   Then top it off with the view, WOWWWWW!!!!!!   You will feel amazing, the air, the view, everything is just glorious.   

At the top to the right, there is a gate that kind of looks like a cemetery gate, walk thru, it's like a mini getaway from city life.   It's a mini trail maybe a few hundred feet long, but the view and being surrounded by forestry made it so serene.
author: Roxana N.

description: YOU WILL DIE OF EXHAUSTION, but you will die happy because the view is phenomenal. This whole area is a visual delight--unique homes with fascinating architectural elements everywhere. My legs burned. But my eyes were happy.
author: Christy C.

description:
If you feel like you've completely exhausted your San Francisco to-do list (believe me, it can happen quickly whether or not you actually live here), there's always the stairways. While searching through different lists of "off-the-beaten" things to do in the city, I came across the Lyon Street Steps. Lyon Street Steps is one of 8 different stairways that can be found throughout San Francisco (see more here: http://www.sftourismtips.com/stairways-of-san-francisco.html). Basically, due to the hilly nature of SF, there are going to be some opportunities for architects to use their creativity and construct beautiful steps that carry people from one end of a street to another. The steps on Lyon Street is one such creation. 

Lyon Street Steps, as indicated by its name, is located on Lyon Street right outside San Francisco's Presidio. The really amazing thing about this stairway (as well as the other 7+ in SF), is that it really does serve a necessary purpose. Essentially, these steps facilitate direct access between Green Street (the top), to Vallejo Street (the middle), and to Broadway (the bottom end). And plus, there are actually houses that lie along Lyon, making it imperative for such a stairway to exist. 

My girlfriend and I decided to visit the Lyon Street Steps as part of our whirlwind tour through San Francisco's hidden attractions. The great feature about this place is that it's situated right next to the Presidio, meaning that there shouldn't be TOO much traffic. It's usually very quiet here since it's in a mostly residential neighborhood + there should be PLENTY of parking spaces. You're almost guaranteed to find a spot right in front of the top of the stairway. And, since it's next to the Presidio, why not pass by whenever you plan that one day trip to the famous national park?? I know you're planning on visiting lover's lane anyway ;) 

As many people have mentioned, Lyon Street Steps is GORGEOUS. I don't know who has been hired to keep this area in tip-top shape, but that person should be paid well. It's almost impossible to imagine that Lyon Street Steps is a public space because 1. it's so clean, and 2. the bushes are so well maintained and manicured. This place is totally PERFECT for photographers. Like you don't even need skill to be able to take a great picture. Plus, if you are brave enough to walk down the stairs (kind of steep, but there's guardrails), you will find one of San Francisco's "hearts." Yes, the city has more than just the one in Union Square. I think the heart is a fitting emblem of the beauty and love that this area evokes. 

I totally recommend adventurers and thrill-seekers to come out and explore the Lyon Street Steps. You can definitely spend longer than you plan here. I may actually just drive up and run around the area because it's so beautiful and you can get a workout climbing those stairs. Thus, I give Lyon Street Steps an "omg, I'd travel 2 hours for this." Heck yea, come visit one of the more underrated and lesser-known places in the city! 

Have fun and prosper,
author: Bryan W.

description:
This street is so cool- when you climb up the stairs and look back, you can see The Palace of Arts. I've been here twice and most people come here to see the view or the locals run through. 

The first time was in April and the trees were green. The second time was in February and the trees were pink! 

Lyon Street Steps is a beautiful spot to check out if you're in SF!
author: Evelina K.

description:
Note to self: Do not attempt to run up and down these steps numerous times with your very energetic and athletic friend Fiona, after not having exercised for more than a year. Will wind up in the chiropractic office.
 
Saying that, the Lyon Street Steps are oh-so-San Francisco and a real treat to immerse oneself in. To me they are a celebration of being a local.
author: Camille L.

description:
Beautiful, breathtaking view. 
This is definitely a good spot to work out, or just enjoy the view. 

The steps here are insane and it's definitely going to put you to work! It gets fairly busy with many local residents working out, jogging the stairs. 

Mainly street parking, so prepare to go during off hours if you want to be parked closed by. The area is extremely clean. There's the presidio park nearby so you'll also see families and their kids and dogs.
author: Kaily V.

description:
Beautiful neighborhood surrounding the Lyon Street Steps. Everything from the landscaping and gardens to the exquisite homes along the steps and the view from the top and seeing the bay. It can be breathtaking... 

The homes are something else. I have a few favorites along the way. They are what San Francisco dreams are made of. The gardens are beautiful and expertly manicured. The view from the of the steps is something to behold. You see the Marina, the Palace of Fine Arts and the Bay. It's a great view, a great look. 

Lot's of people are taking photos and even more are using these steps for their aerobic workout. So definitely try and not get in anyone's way. I cant blame them for wanting to workout there. What a backdrop to their exercise... It's too bad the heart sculpture was gone. It was one of the things we wanted to see. It's still a nice SF spot to visit. 

Street parking only. Check the signs for street cleaning. Turn your wheels. This is San Francisco. Hills and inclines are the norm.
author: Chuck D.

description:
Last year, Yuri and I found the Hidden Garden Steps and the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps, but somehow, we missed these Lyon Street Steps...

Thanks to Daniel C. for pointing them out to us!

WOW!  The surrounding gardens are so beautiful!  The landscaping is amazing!  The views of the city are breathtaking!

We were so sad that the Heart Sculpture was missing.  It is one of 131 Hearts in the City of San Francisco.  Hopefully, it's being repaired and will return soon.  We'll visit again and check on it!

Note: The Hearts in San Francisco Project began in 2004 to benefit the San Francisco General Hospital Foundation.  The most famous Heart could be the one at Union Square on the corner of Powell and Post.  This Heart is named "America's Greatest City By the Bay" and was created by Tony Bennett who sang, " I Left My Heart in San Francisco".
author: Nadine C.

description:
So. Kinduv a not-so spur of the moment trip to SF this morning (1/18). As soon as I rolled into bed trying to readjust my clock on a night off, I rolled out seeing as the clock read close to 0445. I'm usually up an hour after to get my fasting workouts done in the morning anyway.

I wanted to keep today's activity outdoors as I'm still coming down from a week-long virus.. so whaddaya do? Don't check the weather, throw on your regularly-layered "SJ" gear and make an hr+ trek up to The City in sketchy overcast... solid sponto-thinking on my part, no?

These steps were wettt when I got here! It was cold, dark and hard to read parking signs despite the generous streetspace up on Broadway. Currently there's construction going on in the area, don't think I need to say come early.

Lyons has its varying degrees of inclines, flat breaks and step sizings. I'm more used to having a difficult leg towards the top of stairwells like this, but here it gets worse going down. Steps are wide and long coming from the top with some breaks around the big house and steep and narrow on the last two flights.

I'm sure the view's a lot more pleasant on a nicer day.. but is it worth the drive? Maybe. Probably more worth it for locals to exert themselves here, but for commuters like me who like to make the most out of their time in SF... you're already gonna be walking the streets anyway. Your thighs will not love you the next day.

Go for it if you're game/athletic/The Rock.
author: Jason A.

description:
"Where you from?"
"What brings you here?"

These were just some of the questions I got asked as I was at the top of the stairs. I obviously looked and acted like a tourist and I don't blame them. I've lived in SF for 24 years (minus 2 years in LA) and this is the first time I've been here. 

The view from top is excellent when there's no fog, but hey, that's Bay Area for you. I was lucky and there were just light scattering of clouds, but overall good visibility. 

The Lyon steps is kinda tucked on the side of Presidio Park and near a lot of expensive houses. Expensive as in millionss (double s was intended). The good thing is the ample amount of parking available. 

As it's a great place to take someone not from SF, I've also learned it's a great place to get your sweat on. There are tons of people going down and up these stairs and people bringing their yoga mats. 

Lyon steps is a great way to start as it can lead to various Presidio trails.
author: Fiona L.

description: Great work out and the best views ever. Lucky to be part of it!!! Also saw many people do by the same and it was inspirational. Any one can do the Lyon Street Steps!!
author: Rosemarie G.

description:
We came here right around sunset and it was so pretty ! The view was great, and there were not many people there at all! Totally awesome photo op. Just some local people exercising on the steps. 
There are a lot of steps and I got a little by tired but the view was totally worth it. There are lots of flowers and one for the heart statues are also there on the way up. 

The only thing is that there were a lot of mosquitos or some other kind of bug there and I got a few bites. The location is also in a residential area so parking is tricky and being really loud would be really rude I think.
author: Seia W.

description:
Lyon street steps is a must every time I visit San Francisco. For the gorgeous and expansive views, the gardens, and did I mention the actual steps? Serious calorie burning can happening at the Lyon Street Steps. If you want to exercise outside and enjoy amazing views it's doesn't get better than this. If you're cruising around the city and want to check it out it's greedy for that too! I do recommend Wearing comfortable shoes- that way the walk up isn't so painful. The walk up
Is well worth it!
author: Isabella J.

description:
Wanna workout?

Wanna spot one of those amazing San Fran Heart sculptures? 

Wanna beautiful panoramic view of the Bay?

Wanna capture some of San Fran's most beautiful homes?

Go to the Lyon Street Steps and get it all.

~Christy
author: Christy A.

description:
Lyfted to the steps but "unfortunately" was taken to the top of the stairs instead of the bottom.  Aw man...guess we can't climb it.  Darn.

There are several people working out at the top of the steps.  From instructor-guided workout groups to people doing burpees on their own, this is a GREAT alternative to your standard gym.  The rewarding view of the ocean + city is absolutely incredible.  If you go down one flight, you'll also get this take pictures with an SF heart. 

Def recommend, and also to stop by the Andy Goldsworthy's Wood Line and Lover's Lane just a block away for an easy walking trail.
author: Jeff T.

description: Breathtakingly beautiful. There's quite a view from here, both up at the steps and down from. It's a lot of cardio, but the sight is worth it.
author: Lisa D.

description: I feel these are the next level steps for after walking up Moraga Steps. When you walk up the first flight of steps, once you get to the top, you think it's over. But, that's only the beginning! That wasn't actually the actual Lyon Steps. There are two more flights of steps after the entrance. You may be left out of breath after getting to the top, but trust me, the cardio game is worth it. The view of the bay is amazing! On a bright day, you get a view of the beautiful waters and the bright blue skies. You can see the Palace of Fine Arts in the distance. Halfway through the steps, there's a garden area and ledge to take pictures. Also, there's a heart shaped monument that people enjoy taking pictures with as they're running the flights of steps. The views are amazing and while you're at it, you're upping your cardio as well! Definitely be ready to sweat buckets afterwards!
author: Brandon D.

description:
Don't be a sissy. I saw a pregnant lady climbing these steps!

How many steps exactly? about 330. At a very, very steep incline.

The Lyon Steps are SF's worst kept secret. (This and anything with the words "hidden gems" in a yelp review!) But I ain't hating! if you are standing at the top of these steps with your jaw dropped down to the ground and are just stunned by the magnificent views of the bay, the golden dome of Palace of Fine Arts and the mysterious forest that is the Presidio, SF has definitely done its job. Just give way to the serious boot camp work out folks who will breathe down on your neck if you're sloooow to climb these steps. 

Tourists have managed to find these steps because the 45 bus drops you off at Union/Baker sts. and it's a short walk from there. Parking is never an issue around here either. No matter whichever way you get here, save some time to gawk at Billionaire's Row (mansions on Broadway st) and wish/dream how it is to live inside these houses. I know I have!
author: Janice C.

description:
[Out-of-Towner Review]

Sweat. Check.
The view. Check.
People watching. Check.
Public Heart. Check.
Beautiful Homes. Check.

Funny thing is, there are two sets of steps here and there are THREE different streets you can use to park to get to any beginning or end of either set. But we didn't know that, so like touristy Sacramentans we started at the very bottom (insert Drake voice), no we're here!

We did this leisurely, but I loved seeing people use them for their workout. I was sympathy sweating for them. Definitely a spot that has high foot traffic, but it's a great, quick little spot to visit. You get a great view of the bay and a semi decent view of the Palace of Fine Arts.

I loved seeing another "Public Heart" here too. Finding these all over the City makes me smile. It's interesting that there is a gorgeous home right at this spot, but it's gorgeous, to say the least!

Tourist or local, they're good for everyone!
author: Steph G.

description:
One of the best places to get a natural cardio workout. 

Amazing views of the San Francisco Bay, The Presidio, and Pacific heights Mansions.

Just look out for all the MILF's running up and down the stairs with commando workout attitudes.

Tourists  Definitely  a great off the beaten path place to visit.
author: David G.

description: This is a steep hike, and it's beautiful! I was hiking with my mom the other day. So yes, we did need to stop once in a while to enjoy the scene (actaully taking a break). You get to have a very nice view of the city. You will enjoy it!
author: Missy P.

description:
These are a short distance of stairs that provide a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge at a distance.  For those coming for the view, you will be satisfied at the photo opportunities up here.  But the main purpose of these stairs is to burn calories and work those leg muscles!

After eating all the fantastic food in San Francisco, I desperately looked for a place where it would provide a nice scenery, but also giving me a good work out.  I found the right place here; it was stairs and more stairs.  It wasn't too hard, as the steps were actually low and flat, so it was easy to keep going.   You can probably go up and down several times before you actually feel winded and exhausted.

Parking is plentiful on the street and on the top is an entrance to a park that leads to several walking trails.  Bring some water, run those steps, and turn back and enjoy the view!
author: David L.

description: Great place to get some stair work done. The first round of going up and down is ok, but repeat this several times and the workout is killer. I ran through the city the other day and hit Lyon Street Stairs. Did 4 rounds in between my run and I definitely felt the burn. The view is SO AMAZING-- it's motivation to keep going up to see it again.
author: Elysse P.

description:
A hidden gem in the Pacific Heights neighborhood!

I was staying with a friend in Cow Hollow during my trip to SF. One afternoon, we decided to explore her neighborhood since it was a beautiful sunny day (apparently very rare in SF) and we eventually stumbled to the bottom of the Lyon Street Steps.  What followed was experiencing one of the most beautiful spots in San Francisco. 

There are several sets of steps. The middle of the staircase has a beautiful heart shaped sculpture - a great spot for a photo op. The very top of the steps has the most breathtaking panoramic views of the Bay Palace of Fine Arts, neighborhood mansions, Presidio forest and even Alcatraz in sight. 

The steps are steep, but this spot is scenic and worth doing. It also seems to be a popular place for locals to work out as we saw several (athletic) people running up and down the stairs. Someone even did a few pushups and sit-ups at the top - so intense. 

Highly recommend the Lyon Steps for scenic views of the bay and a less touristy spot in the city! A beautiful spot in SF.
author: Syyu C.

description:
Gorgeous set of steps that provides picture-perfect views of Alcatraz and the Bay while running alongside a number of mansions, including that of Sen. Dianne Feinstein, in an exclusive neighborhood. 

Although many West Bay locals go up and down these steps as part of their workout routines, there usually isn't a whole lot of douchery or entitlement on display here, as joggers and tourists alike usually watch out and make room for others accordingly. Definitely worth a visit, especially as part of a walk through Pacific Heights.
author: Vincent L.

description:
" I LEFT MY HEART IN SAN FRANCISCO" 

After reading the little placard that was by the heart, I understand why I hear that phrase a lot. It stated that the Hearts of San Francisco, this golden heart was one of 130 sculptures beautifully and inspired heart sculptures that were created by local Bay Area artists in an exhibit of public hearts project that was debuted in 2004. Never realized that there were that many hearts. I'd love to see all the hearts in my lifetime.

I was on a hunt for hearts during my past SF day trip with a friend. She told me about this Lyon Street Steps that beholds a golden heart. It's another hidden gem spot located in the Pacific Heights neighborhood. Such a beautiful sight to take pictures at and also overlooking the neighborhood. SF must love their stairs, I've seen so many during this one day trip to SF. Of course, we weren't prepared for hiking another set of stairs after coming from the mosaic steps. But I've seen a few people do their cardio here. Although it looks pretty intense, it'll probably take me a while just to get up there. haha.
author: Roxanne Lynn T.

description: Great views of the ocean, palace of fine arts. It seems like a great place to work out as well because running up and down the stairs sure made me tired! There's also a SF heart there that makes it the picturesque spot! Not many tourists so ample space to take great photos!
author: Sunny K.

description: I didn't actually climb all the stairs but if you park on top and walk towards this area, you won't be disappointed with the beautiful view of San Fran.  There is a ton of parking and the Lyon Street Steps are surrounded by amazing homes that can stir envy in the most humble of people.
author: Monica G.

description: You want to do some nice legs workout? This is the perfect opportunity. What a view, amazing stairs, pretty heart for the 'picture with a SF hearts' selfie collection. Free parking nearby at this beautiful Pacific Heights neighborhood. In a sunny day is just such a wonderful place to get an amazing view of the ocean and do some 'street yoga' or any soft workout (I saw some ladies with their mats and weights and it was very motivational'. Even though you will see so many people running up and down those stairs, there is a sense or order that is actually quite impressive.
author: Carmen V.

description:
If you're looking to get your ass kicked by some steps, this set is more appropriate than the 16th Avenue Tiled ones.  Motivation will come as you watch tons of other people run up and down with you.  Occasionally, there will be tourists who get dropped off at the top (lucky bastards) only to get winded just coming down.

Once you've done this however many times, you can cool off by continuing the walk at the bottom towards Palace of Fine Arts.  The sidewalk to that area is wide so you walk or run comfortably.  

At Lyon and Lombard St., you'll get to these set of buildings that look like they're in a park.  You can walk through, lay on the grass, or use the bathrooms at Starbucks.  Truly a lovely way to spend an afternoon!
author: Shannon L.

description: I rarely climb these steps since I work in the neighborhood. Lots of people cross train here.
author: Julio B.

description: The best thing about the Lyon Street Steps is the view. A prominent part of the steps is the "Heart of SF", which also makes for great pictures. There are lots of people working out- running up and down the steps. While I on the other hand was trying to catch my breath.
author: Helen H.

description:
Some say this place is one of the  "Top 10 THE Best Places to  Kiss in San Francisco..other's say it is a runner's dream.
Either way - it will take your breath away!
Count the steps - I Double Dare you...
author: Miami S.

description:
332 beautifully manicured steps with incredible views! The steps are a little busy with people working out and running up and down, but everyone worked well together no matter the pace. Good mix of people just casually walking around too.

Worth a visit regardless of whether you want a workout. The neighborhood includes mind-boggling multi-million dollar mansions, and the view goes for miles.
author: Miranda D.

description: As long as there are not to many joggers these steps amazing. A work out, a view and nice gardens. A must do in SF.
author: Kelli C.

description: Drove up here from Andy Goldsworthy's Wood Line, so we didn't have to trek on the super steep slope to the top of the stairs. The view was amazing, and going down and up the stairs was surprisingly not too tiring because the steps are pretty shallow. The steps are in a nice neighborhood in the Presidio, so definitely check it out if you're hiking in Lands' End and want another gorgeous view!
author: Kimberly K.

description: So I used to live 3 blocks from here and walked my dogs here almost every day. One of the best views in the city!!!
author: Andrew K.

description:
This is definitely a hidden treasure of SF. My group of friends exploring SF just finished exploring the 16th Avenue Tiled Steps and they hated me for wanting to stop by another steps tourist attraction. We parked in the neighborhood and walked to the set of stairs. Originally, we weren't going to go up because the firs set of stairs looked boring and plain so we sent our two guys to go up and tell us if it's worth it to go up to the 2nd flight of stairs.

And they reported back that it is pretty! So the girls made the trek up the stairs, slowly but surely. And at the second set, there is one of those SF hearts and it was decorated with flowers all around. After a few minutes of catching our breaths, we squeezed in a few photo ops and continued on our exploring SF agenda.
author: Minh-An C.

description: I love exploring SF whenever I'm back. We went here just to check it out and it was busy with a bunch of people working out! The stairs are steep and perfect for a leg workout. Not to mention the view from the top is breathtaking (as are most views from Pac Heights). Just a nice place for a walk or workout.
author: Elaine N.

description: Gorgeous set of stairs they lead you up to a great view of the bay. It was clear but not sunny in the November Sunday but the view was still amazing. Lots of people doing exercise here as the staircases provide quite the cardio! If you are visiting and stopping by in the marina, check it out, it's definitely a new fave place of mine!
author: Betty C.

description:
I went to Lyon and Green St.
Parked.

It's a dead end leading to Lyon Street Steps but where Lyon meets Green, there's a house that was used as Grove High School in Princess Diaries. I have nieces. I love Princess Diaries. 

Lyon Street Steps are two sets of steps with one of the hearts of San Francisco between the two sets. These steps connect Pacific Heights to Cow Hollow.. all 244 steps of them. It's a good workout.. Just ask all the people that run up and down these steps. People lapped me. It was a little ridiculous. The top of the steps are at Lyon and Broadway where you can take in some views.. You can take in this view all the way back down actually but you can appreciate it more at the top where you don't have to worry about each step you take and people passing you by..
author: O M G.

description:
I absolutely love this place. My boyfriend and I came here to take maternity pictures. It was absolutely breathtaking. We were so pleased with the view of the city we climbed every step. Mind you I'm 9 months pregnant and die in 9 days. If I can climb those steps I know you can too. 

If you live in the city or anywhere in the baby you should pay this place a visit. I moved to the bay two years ago and this was my first time to this place. If it wasn't for maternity shoot I would have never found this place.

If I live here in the city I would probably be here every weekend running those steps. There are at least 200 steps here. It's worth the try if you want some intense workout while overlooking the city. 

You will not regret coming here I promise you. Be sure to come in your tennis shoes though because there ARE A LOT OF STEPS!!!!
author: Kelly L.

description:
Another Gem in San Francisco with an AMAZING view!!! This view looks out into the ocean towards Alcatraz and the end of the warf/ where the presido is. The Lyon Street Steps are located in Pacific Heights above the Palace of Fine Arts. 

These stairs are no joke!! It is a great way to enjoy beautiful scenery while getting a killer workout. They have about 3 blocks worth of stairs upward. Many locals come here to run up and down the stairs to get their work out. While tourists climb to the top to enjoy the view. Either or Lyon Street Steps are the perfect for either or. 

Now that I know what I am in for, I will definitely come more prepared with running shoes and workout gear, because the workout we got just walking up and down was great, I can only imagine the workout someone could get running up and down!!!
author: Rochelle E.

description: Secret spot around the city! Must place to go for a beautiful view of the city. Princess Diaries fans: down the street you'll find the location of Grove High School
author: Florence D.

description: First of all steps are one of my biggest fears along with heights! And these were so worth getting over my fear! Beautiful views! People working out were really nice about me going slow going down as I stayed to one side. Definitely worth the stop!
author: Lydia V.

description:
STAIRMASTER PLUS BUTT LIFT

The stairs start at Lyon/Green and go up to Lyon/Broadway. This is the last flight of steps, all nicely landscaped and pretty (unlike the first set of steps at the bottom):
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lyon-street-steps-san-francisco?userid=QhYJx2jQdPuSq3fGe3aGcA#e1DG7GOmI0541PN47a3O-g

There are approximately 250 stairs and at the top you are rewarded with stunning views of the bay, Alcatraz, and the bridge (depending on how clear it is). 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lyon-street-steps-san-francisco?select=5hCYVWg9qndc0HCcfcQ3ig#5hCYVWg9qndc0HCcfcQ3ig

There are crazy ass ninjas who run up and down this for exercise, and there are some who walk up one flight and give up and go back down. Then there are some who drive to the top of the steps and park (on Broadway) for free and just take in the beautiful scenery. Don't judge. If you still want more, there are some hiking trails at the top of the steps that go into the "forest" but we didn't venture out there this time.

Thank you Phillip for leading the way. This place was a true hidden gem! We even got to catch a glimpse of the City Grazers (goats) who were still munching away!
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/lyon-street-steps-san-francisco?select=Ry1QRE_NtmgCn_rjduIyrw#Ry1QRE_NtmgCn_rjduIyrw

Best of all, it was FREE!
author: Lori I.

description: First came to these stairs with my love. It was one of our first few places we had gone together. Tonight came back with my bestie. Great place, gorgeous view, hick of an exercise
author: Samineh H.

description:
The address listed for the Lyon Street Steps should be changed from Lyon Street & Green Street to Lyon Street & Broadway Street.  If you go to Lyon & Green, you'll be at the bottom of the steps, which is nothing special.  So, type into your GPS Lyon Street & Broadway Street and you'll be at the top of the steps.

At the top of the steps, there are stunning views of San Francisco facing north towards the bay.  From here, you can see Cow Hollow, the Palace of Fine Arts and the Marina District.  The steps themselves are located in Pacific Heights.  These neighborhoods are mostly residential and very ritzy.  The good thing about this is parking is easy to find.  There isn't much here, so the area isn't touristy nor trafficky.

A lot of folks like to exercise on the steps.  There are eight flights of 15 steps on the upper, more "scenic" and decorative, section of the steps.  There are two flights of 62 steps on the lower section that ends at Green St.  That's 244 steps total.  I don't recommend walking them unless you're specifically looking for a workout.

It's widely known California Senator Dianne Feinstein owns a house on the steps.  Guess which one it is.  The entire stretch of steps is privately landscaped, so it always look quite nice.  The steps are certainly worth a visit if you have a car and you're in the area.  Visiting during the daytime is better.  The fancy houses are fun to look at and admire too.
author: Daniel B.

description:
I got bored at the gym so I yelped "best stair workout". Low and behold, I came across this gem. 

I love living in this city and still finding new places to go. Not crowded when I went and even with the flux of people passing through and working out, it was never packed and I got my workout on peacefully. I'm always looking for stairs to utilize for my workouts and I would recommend this spot. 

The view is toward the ocean and the north point area. Not 360, but it was nice to see something I don't always see. And there's an entrance to the presidio next to it.
author: Jenna R.

description:
Location Location Location

The steps themselves are not the focal point.  But - Wow! - everything around them certainly is!  If you like large, expensive homes, beautiful gardens, and amazing views of the bay, these are the steps for you!
author: Ted Q.

description:
Great quick set of stairs with a nice view. The neighborhood is amazing - so many extravagant, fancy hou$es. If you must choose only one set of stairs in SF, though, do the 16th ave tiled stairs - much better view and less crowded. 

I did this on the way to Lombard St. (taking the bus) which turned out to be a good route. 

It's pretty entertaining to watch all the people working out. They sure do love these stairs.
author: Marcia N.

description: Who needs a stairmaster when you have the Lyon Street Steps?  This is a popular place for people getting their fitness on.  However, I wasn't coming here to run up and down the steps while carrying two 5-gallon water jugs.  I actually just wanted to check out the garden in front of Senator Feinstein's home and also see the view from the top of the staircase.  This neighborhood is filled with multi-million dollar homes only one could dream of living in.  Ocean views are beautiful and the Lyon Street Steps with surrounding landscaping add to the appeal of the area.  One of the 130 hearts around the city are found here - makes for a nice photo-op.  There are two sets of stairs but nothing too challenging unless you plan to join the cross-fitters!
author: Liv A.

description:
Damn.  What a workout!  The view ain't too shabby either.  :)

Watch out for all the other people working out.  They're like sweaty machines out there!  It's also great motivation because everyone running the steps is in incredible shape. 

The air is so fresh that if you're used to LA air like I am, it'll hurt your lungs.  Just saying
author: Kristin H.

description: Not sure if I derped and if there is more to these steps but as I was walking toward the Presidio Park, I came upon the steps. I didnt realize it warranted its own yelp page since I thought it was part of the Presidio. It has a nice view of the city as you walk down and it will lead you to the Palace of Fine Arts or the park. This is a short staircase but I guess if you came here to work out and went up and down the stairs, then it would be legit. Make sure to take a photo with one of the SF hearts!
author: Amy H.

description: Long steep set of stairs right next to the Presidio with the hearts (next to Dianne Feinstein's house) and lots of exercisers. If you can avoid the sweaty people and make it up the stairs you'll be rewarded with some great views of the Marina.
author: Jean K.

description:
Oh how I love outdoor training in San Francisco. The weather is always nice, the scenery is beautiful and there's plenty of hills and stairs to challenge your runs. The Lyon street stairs is one of my favorite outdoor workout spots. The stairs are super long and get steeper towards the bottom. There's no doubt that you'll get a great cardio workout regardless of your athleticism. 

Depending on when you go, you may run into bootcamp classes, teams and other exercisers. I like to make my rounds here in the mornings, just as the sun is rising and the temperatures are cool. 

You get picturesque views of the bay, Palace of Fine Arts, Marina, etc. It's also in a nice and bougie neighborhood and parking is pretty easy here.
author: Helen C.

description:
Get steps for a killer workout! The views are gorgeous and the air is fresh & clean.

Its also great inspiration once you've reach the top and see the view, take a deep breath and be happy & thankful for the life you live.
author: Court S.

description:
Left... Left... Left, Right, Left! 

If you're interested in undergoing your own personal bootcamp then search no further! Lyon Street Steps will whip your tush right into shape. 

Unassumingly so, I took the challenge of these steps as if it were a piece of cake. Half way up the first flight, I was already panting and out of breath. My calves and thighs were buuuurning.

After reaching the very top, I paused for a moment to regain my strength and slowly began to descend down the stairs. Thank goodness for side rails; my legs felt like jelly and I feared I might tumble down the rest of the way.

Roughly three days after, my legs were still sore. I've been maneuvering myself throughout the city like a bow legged cowboy, Yosemite Sam style, grimacing each time I dropped something on the floor and had to stoop down to pick it up. 

With all that said, no pain, no gain. These steps will surely deliver results if you stick with it long enough. Then again, I'm still a work in progress. I'll let you know when I get thurrrr.

This is an awesome way to challenge your endurance and a great addition to any workout regimen!

Atten-hut!
author: Ann S.

description:
This is a must visit plce of San Francisco for sure if you like beautiful views! I would imagine it's hard to get to this area if you don't have a car, but it's worth the Uber fare, trust me! There are some cool things to see on the way to the top of the view, so remember to stop by and take pictures.  
One slightly annoying catch about this place was that there's always somebody working out and running up and down the steps, so you're always in somebody's way.  
While you're here in the city remember to visit the Moraga steps too!
author: Vishaal P.

description:
I wished I would've guzzled some h20 along with my mass amounts of coffee before going to this gem of SF. 

Even though I don't have a fitbit (yet,) I ask Colin how many steps we are at when we get to spend the day together. Knowing this and how I was complaining about my pants not fitting after indulging (a lot) in the city this week, he planned a date here. (What a catch, huh?)

Besides the breathtaking views and literal breathtaking steps, I might not have to leave my then tight pants in San Francisco!

Go. Smell the flowers. Be prepared to de-layer. Pet some really cute dogs that are along with their athletic mom or dad.
author: Sarah M.

description:
There's nothing quite like trying to get to your destination and stumbling on a mini-gym in downtown San Francisco. Impromptu work out, anyone? Okay, I lied. There are better things in life, but you get one in when you can, right? Even if you're wearing dress shoes and on your way to meet some people. What's a little sweat?

I was floored when I got to the top of the street steps. What a gorgeous view --- overlooking San Francisco. It stopped me dead in my tracks. The smells, the sounds, the flood of endorphins that comes after running up so many steps. If I lived in San Francisco, I'd come here often. It wasn't too crowded for a Sunday afternoon (I wonder what it's like in the mornings?) and a total must-visit if you enjoy city views, exercise and fresh air.
author: Alex L.

description: Today was a cloudy gloomy day so I decided to head out to Lyon Street steps- one of the many items on my bucket list of places to explore in SF. There are three sets of stairs here- not just one set like I thought! Lots of in shape people running up and down these steps, sweating and out of breath when they reached the top, but they would turn around and do it all over again! Definitely a great place to check out if you want to change up your workout. The area is surrounded by multi-million dollar homes with great architecture which makes it a unique spot in the city to explore. It was also just a few blocks from the Presidio entrance that has a Starbucks if you need a restroom break or just want to hang out in a great relaxing setting.
author: Elaine Tiffany P.

description: One of the hidden gems of SF. Top 10 views? I think so. Take a drive through the neighborhood while you're at it. $10 million dollar homes definitely give you something to think about.
author: Joshua F.

description:
If you're in the area, definitely take a walk up and down these steps. I had just visited the Disney Museum, and this was a nice walk over.

You'll have to avoid a few joggers, but it's a great view that's well worth the mild panting going up the stairs may induce.
author: Ryan H.

description: Amazing view of this gorgeous city  if you go to the too sure will you will get your heart rate up.
author: Angiel S.

description:
Blocks have 3 hr free parking? Check
Getting your exercise on? Definitely Check
Amazing view at the top of the steps? Check..well, only when you're blessed with a rare bright and sunny day in San Francisco. 

The first leg of the steps from Green street is STEEP. Man, don't take it lightly. I was huffing and puffing by the time I got to the bleeding bird heart thing. Now the 2nd leg of the steps are not too bad. and by the time you get up there, you'll be hit with an amazing, breathless (heh) view. 

After you're done with this, you can head down to visit the Palace of Fine Arts or wander around Laurel Village for a cup of coffee. :)
author: Sandra L.

description: Absolutely wonderful!  We enjoyed the staircase - and views! - on a lovely Saturday afternoon. I can see how it may be crowded so try to go mid-day.
author: Laura S.

description:
By far, this remains one of my favorite stairways in SF.  On a clear day, the sweeping and grandiose views of the Pacific Height palatial residences, the GG bridge, Alcatraz, Marin County (Tiburon & Sausalito) and the BAY are just breathtaking and awe-inspiring.  I always blame the runner's high or utter exhaustion and pain after completing stair climbs, but I've been known to weep over the beauty when I reach the top landing.

Not to mention, you can get a killer core, quad and glute work-out here.  A fellow NPC bodybuilding competitor almost killed me here during a training day this week.  I ran the full stairs once, performed lunges, squats and calf-raises and then, back to back stair climb repeats followed by more lunges, squats and calf-raises...and one more run up the full set of stairs and then, a half set of stairs.  Needless to say, I was DYING by the time we hit our last set of lunges and squats.  

If you happened to remember witnessing a little Asian lady crying at the bottom of the stairs while performing squats...well, that was me... hahaha.  OMG!   Best memories!
author: Hiromi N.

description: I loved this place! I went for an exercise and this was my exercise route: start from top of lyon steps and go down all the way, go to palace of fine arts and go around the small lake, come back to lyon steps via presidio park, and climb up the lyon steps! The view is amazing from up there and it's a great exercise place to go for locals.
author: Erika S.

description: Love the incredible stair cases in San Francisco. Lyon Street Steps are no exception! They are super intense. Lace up and give running them a shot. There is a gorgeous heart in the center or you can simply soak in the view from the top. It's located in a stunning neighborhood and is worth a visit. Word to the wise: tour buses stop here so go earlier in the morning to avoid the chaos!
author: Kari G.

description: Wow, so many intense people working out here and with such impressive bodies, at that. Figures, as these stairs are in-tense. Up close, the reward is definitely the beautifully landscaped and well-maintained gardens, as well as impressive homes. The SF heart with a flying bird in the middle of the main garden was a pleasant find. As you reach higher and higher, the overlooking view of the bay is also a nice perk. Keep right to stay out of the way of the intense stair climbers. The area is a nice mix of tourists and locals, which I appreciated.
author: Phoebe C.

description:
Holy crap. There are so many stairs. I thought there were only a few sets but it turns out there are much more. I only made i up two sets but I could tell the view was pretty amazing. It's a bit out there in the city, but if you want to get some good exercise and some nice views of SF, by all means seek it out. 

If you want to get into shape, run or walk up these stairs regularly you'll be bootielicious in no time. I plan on finding more steps like these to get into shape after gorging myself...maybe before?
author: Amy J.

description: Great walk, but difficult for people who have children. The view is spectacular and lots of areas to stop and take pictures. Not much of a wait to walk up or down for a Saturday morning.
author: Michele N.

description:
GREAT. WORKOUT. with a great view!

I overheard it was 291 stairs. I did a circuit of 4 sets, at the top did pushups and sit ups then got back to it. My goal is to work my way up to 10 sets by June.

Bonus: one of the SF Hearts is located here!
author: Megan F.

description:
The perfect place to exercise in the northern / Marina / Pacific Heights area of SF. First, parking is free all Saturdays and Sundays (a rarity in SF), and there's a ton of it. Second, everyone is nice and not pushy like other workout / makeout point / tourist / sky viewing areas. 

The stairs are separated in sections and with one of the beautiful SF Hearts art displays. Your water bottles and bags are safe and likely won't be stolen. People are there to jog or walk up the well maintained stairs that lead to a breathtaking view of the city, the Palace of Fine Arts, and the Bay.

Love it. Come workout and get a great view.
author: Chuck N.

description:
What's not to love about these steps?  Great workout, easily accessible for most parts of The City, and, oh yeah, kick ass views!!

So usually when I am in town, I will run from my hotel through Pac Hts and end up at the steps, hit them for a while, and run back. Perfect workout and a perfect route to see some of the great parts of The City. Right at the edge of Pac Hts and the Presidio, the views can distract you from your workout, and, frankly, they should!  The bottom half of the steps is a little narrower and steeper, with the top half being wider with a ton of perfectly manicured landscaping.  At the top, there is plenty of room to get in sit ups, push ups, or using your thigh master between trips to the bottom and back.  You can get a great workout here if you hit it hard, and there are plenty of people that do.  

On weekends it can get crowded with some tourists milling about, taking pictures, and all the stuff that tourist typically do.  They can and do slow down a workout (especially on the top half), but that's the price you pay when you choose to exercise at a venue with a great view.  Hit the stairs hard and then enjoy the surrounding as you are catching your breath!!
author: Gee W.

description: Went up and down the steps 2x. 3 days later I'm still feeling it in my legs! Definitely a great workout! Will be back for more happy but not so fun pain :)
author: Nimisa P.

description:
These steps will make you oooo,  ahhhh, and ugh.  

From the bottom, make your way up the first two sets of extremely steep cement steps.  This is the "ugh" part.  This will be tough for first-timers, but an addictive challenge for regulars who come here for a gruesome workout fix.  At the top of these steep steps, you will come to another set of wider steps leading up to some of the most beautiful homes in the Marina.  This is the "oooo" part.  Along the way, you will be surrounded with beautiful flowers and architecture.  When you finally reach the top, you will be rewarded with the most breathtaking view of the Marina.  You guessed it.  This is the "ahhhh" part.  It is worth every dreadful step.

Now, take a deep breath and make your way back down so you can make your way back up all over again.  Your butt and calves will thank you.  The most I've done in one visit is 9 times.  Bring a face towel.  You will be sweating.  Bring a camera.  You will want to capture the scenery.
author: Gloria Y.

description:
My hiking buddies and I are in perfect agreement that this is the best workout ever for hiking and endurance training.  The view is phenomenal and the often time cool weather is the best.   Its getting to be a little more crowded these days, but still the best workout ever.  

I've done these steps in my third trimester, with my baby strapped on a hiking carrier, and on my own.   I always walk away feeling like I've done good - and I'm going to feel some pain.  :D
author: Regi K.

description:
Great place go to for an outdoor workout! It's not an urban hike, or any hike for that matter.  You can either start at Broadway or at Green.  The section from Broadway to Vallejo is slightly easier because the steps are larger, while the section from Vallejo to Green is steeper and narrower. 

Whether you're looking at the mansions on Billionaire's Row or the view of the Palace of Fine Arts, there are great views all around.

I guess you could say that this is San Francisco's version of the Santa Monica Stairs.
author: Audrey C.

description: Great place to run up and down the stairs with an amazing view!!!  Seriously, you'll get vertigo, but who cares... you can recover from the dizziness by enjoying the view.
author: Vicky T.

description:
Just ran the Lyon Street Steps during this week's beer run and wow was it an absolute pace-killer. On the flip side, it made the beer after taste extra good. 

Running up the first flight, you realize you are beginning to lose some steam but that's okay because you are almost at the top. Then BAM! You realize that's just the first of three flights. The run up the steps becomes a brisk climb and then a slow trudge. The greenery is pretty though and the view once you get to the top makes it all worthwhile. 

If you want to add some spice into your run, the Lyon Street Steps will definitely add some challenge to it but think about the extra calories burned... and the lovely view when you are done.
author: Jon L.

description:
The views, houses and garden are amazing. The steps can give you a good jump start work out. Never been too crowded when Ive been here.

Many doing these steps and looking at these homes makes you dream about what could be then when you finish and wake up then leave the area, damn.

This is another somewhat hidden SF gem. And parking around here isnt too bad at all.
author: T C.

description:
5 stars for the level of difficulty of running up and down these stairs + the beautiful view.

It's been a while since I came here to test my endurance. Last time, I couldn't make it up and down without taking 2-3 breaks. It's a difficult work out but for the fresh air, nice views, and a free "stair master," it is worth it. 

By the way, in the middle of the stairs, there's a gold SF Heart with a bird on it. How pretty!  

Also, if you've ever watched the Princess Diaries, one of the buildings they used in the movie is just down the hill.
author: Connie Y.

description:
I'm sitting here typing between rounds with the rolling pin on my quads after tackling these steps yesterday for the first time.  I've been running, climbing hills, and using the elliptical sporadically and these stairs kicked my ass - legs felt like Jell-o after just one time up and down the full set of stairs.

Now, don't get me wrong - I ran there from Crissy Field, ran up the hill to the steps, THEN ran up the steps, so I don't want to hear any "you need to do these steps at least twice for a real workout" business.  Crissy Field to the top of the steps and back is about a 22 minute round trip.  If you're looking for a good 20-30 minute strenuous workout, look no further.

Ran up the bottom two flights two steps at a time, then did the next 1 step at a time, then alternated 1 and 2 to the top.  The top part is a blur - I was in survival mode, basically, since the legs felt like noodles after the second flight.

Not too busy at mid-day on a Tuesday.  There were a few other runners here, but none of the crowds that others have mentioned.

These are going to end up part of the workout rotation to keep it interesting, and I'll be making excuses to go into the city just to tackle them.  I'll build up those Rickey Henderson legs one of these days . . .
author: Joe B.

description:
Oh my golly goodness....what is there not to love about this place!

Came here on a rainy day and I loved everything about it!!!

I died making it up the first 2 batch of STEEP stairs, and saw that I was the only one out of breath...then turned around...Oh BOY!  loved the view.

As we made it all the way to the top oh boy...it started sprinkling, sun was peaking through the clouds...it was just so perfect. I wanna live here just to go up and down the steps everyday....prolly need to find a side business to make that happen :-I

By the way the houses along the stairs are nice too.
author: Navdha V.

description:
A nice challenge for anyone who likes running up and down stairs.  The first half is a lot harder than the second half.  The first flight is steeper and narrower while the second flight has wider steps that are friendlier to anyone who likes going up two at a time. 

I highly recommend you come here to catch an awesome view of the Marina District.  It took me like 4  hours to get here from DTSF because I had no sense of direction and ended up getting lost.  Good thing there were a bunch of nice folks here willing to give me direction.

I did the steps 2.5 times and was pooped.  It might also have been because I did the Filbert Street steps earlier in the day, but I really think the Lyon Street Step Sisters (har har har) will give you a run for your money!
author: May W.

description:
There is nothing to it by walking down these mile-long steps with glamorous views of Pacific Heights and the Marina District.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/5ZoeIusBHVOP1Fip5Hydtw?select=GrQZJqu0cl4S_UGA_2D2aw

But going back and walking back up these steep stairs:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/5ZoeIusBHVOP1Fip5Hydtw?select=fgaxaWbxHNWlswydpDnEaA

SCREW THAT... unless there is an El Farolito Super Burrito waiting for me on top of Broadway St.
author: Matt G.

description:
Started from Broadway/Lyon, walked down to Green, up, down, up, down, up.

Done,  I was pooped and sweaty.
author: qirk z.

description:
I haven't felt my heart rate get this high in so long. This is an excellent place to work out and there were even some people giving away coconut water! I'm sore now.

There was lots of parking, even on a beautiful day, near the top.
author: Tomas P.

description: This is definitely a hidden treasure of SF.
author: Gavin M.

description:
Awesome views all around and a great workout to boot!  Walking distance from Palace of Fine Arts and always seems like parking is available. 

There's a good mix of people getting their workout in and tourists, which at times block the stairways for others. 

At the top of the stairs (Broadway and Lyon) walk about 200 feet past the Presidio gate for a stunning view of Alcatraz.
author: Christina H.

description:
Lyon Street Stairs is a great place to get a hard work out. It is comprise of three sections. The bottom of the stairs is located at Lyon Street and Green Street. 

From there it is 120 small but grueling steps, up Lyon Street, to the top of the first section. Then you must walk across a cul-de-sac (Vallejo Street) to another set of 35 wider spaced steps that take you around a beautifully planted garden. On the other side of the garden is the remaining 120 steps up that will take you to Broadway Street, where you can celebrate your cardiovascular victory! 

It's a very hard work out but the people that go there are generally very nice, pleasant and nonjudgmental. Stay to the right if you are a beginner and get motivation from the pros. Go at your own pace and you will make it to the top! 

Each time I do it, it gets easier and I feel healthier and I know you will too. Good Luck!
author: Joyce H.

description: Best workout in Cow Hollow and perhaps in all of Marina/Pac Heights! Go with some friends because you will need the encouragement. A couple of times up and down and your heart will want to pop out of your chest and your legs will feel like overcooked spaghetti. Time efficient, fun workout with a view!
author: Annika B.

description: This was one of my favorite places in SF to work out for years- Beautiful views of Pacific Heights, the Presidio and the Marina. I'd actually do the stairs several times and then run to the GG Bridge along the Marina. I loved seeing the new flowers and plants each season, really impeccably cared for. Also, there are benches and things to help with stretching and different exercises. And I loved that I always saw others working out here- even personal trainers, boot camps, etc. Inspiring and felt safe. Best time to go was early in the am so not too many folks and air was fresh and crisp/not too hot. I've moved from SF, but still remember how much I enjoyed this place.
author: Katie K.

description:
These are the finest stairs in SF. 

I love climbing them. 

I don't like when people congregate halfway up the flight.

Why am I reviewing stairs on Yelp? 

Why are you reading reviews on a set of stairs? How could this review not have 5 stars:

"Err, I didn't like the climb up. Too many stairs. Fog was too dense. The stairs didn't carry me up"

Like... what?
author: Tommy C.

description:
Two times up and down, and I am flat on the floor hyperventilating. Want some serious cardio and butt blasting? Look no further.

And don't forget about the perks!! Easy neighborhood parking, beautiful view (you really are climbing quite high), gorgeous landscaping, huge mansions to gawk at.

Also keep in mind that the stairs are not that wide at some parts. Make room for those crazy sprinters.
author: Diana L.

description:
I was at the bottom. 
Contemplated goin up. Swear.
Gave it one star ONLY because nobody else did & I wanted to be a brat.
I dont work out
author: A L.

description: Love coming here, especially because it's in one of my favorite neighborhoods in SF. It's walking distance to the Palace of Fine Arts, too, if you're feeling ambitious. And that view at the top -- so worth the 5-7 minutes climb. Oh, and parking is never an issue.
author: Diana K.

description: Perfect place to work out outdoors when the weather permits it. Great views of Pac Heights with things like the GG Bridge and Palace of Fine Arts in the distance. If you're looking to take your pups, walk down a block or two and there's a set of older steps that's less crowded and a good workout for your dogs and you.
author: Ashley Nicole C.

description:
To ALL of you amazing people who RUN these stairs, and sometimes two at a time, my hat is off to you.  You guys are sick.

But, I can't give it "Woohoo!  As Good As it Gets!" because if it got any better/harder, I'd be dead.
author: Tamar D.

description:
"Did the Steps" as part of my training for promotion at the Shaolin Temple last summer.  
   I am so GLAD to live in San Francisco and have this available.  NOTHING like almost dying and enjoying the view at the same time.  I love this hilly dilly town.     
   Check out the Moraga steps for more heart stopping and outright gasping views...
author: UnitedStudios S.

description: WHAT!!! the basketball hoop is gone! This is tragic. Used to be gorgeous place to shoot around....how can we get it back?
author: Preston Z.

description:
I love these steps - but they are definitely challenging.  Not exactly the Dipsea.  When the weather and the music on my Ipod is right - I am not complaining.

Rounding this stack can get pretty busy with lots of trainers and teams.  Unfortunately, I have trouble getting my friends to agree to actually hiking these with me.  I recommend hiking with a friend or creating a "balls to the wall" playlist to help you plunge through.   

As with all of the stairs that I recommend - do not forget to hydrate, turn around, and check out the view!
author: Rayna A.

description:
Have your breath taken away...with a workout and a fantastic view !!! 
If you love stairs like I do, this is the place for you. Plenty of room to stretch in between with that amazing view to look at. 
Even better, the Presidio is close by!!!!
author: Quinn S.

description: Me and my honey bunches (of oats) as I like to call her went to the Lyon Street Steps for our honey moon. Let me tell you I was not disappointed. We camped outside for the first three days just observing the steps from a historical perspective (We were both history majors in college). on the fourth day of our wild adventure we decided we were finally gonna climb them. Boy what a treat! It took us only 2 hrs 17 mins to get all the way to the top without rest. We really powered through it! As soon as we got to the top and gazed upon the beautiful San Francisco bay, I looked into her eyes. Nothing in this world could have better reassured me that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with someone than that moment. Thank you Lyon Street Steps for creating this priceless moment for me.
author: Donald W.

description: These are great steps for a full workout, but are also close to a couple of easy trails in the Presidio like Lover's Lane, so if you want a casual walk, the option is there.  The first steps are narrow and steep and the second set are more evenly spaced and at a moderate incline.  The views on top are spectacular.
author: Katharine A.

description: Let the city be your work out and get some killer instagram pictures while you're at it! The steps are definitely a hard work out, like any steep hill in San Francisco you'll be huffing and puffing but at least it's outdoors and you can do it with a group of people. It may not be the cardio workout that you serious gym bunnies look for but it's a nice alternative in my opinion.
author: Sarah M.

description: Another great spot that people love to exercise on. Anyways, such a gorgeous view, if on a clear day. The stairs are nice and even seems like they cut into people's backyard. Definitely an affluent area!
author: Roger A.

description: Walked these on the way to a 5k and back- killer set of stairs with beautiful scenery!
author: Jess T.

description:
Very nice and popular place to go for a workout.  There were a lot of people here when I came for exercise after work one day last week.  The steps on the block between Broadway and Vallejo are of a moderate grade with much nice landscaping.  The steps on the next block then, between Vallejo and Green, are much steeper and can be a test of knee power when going in the downhill direction.

Now that I rediscovered this spot as a place for exercise, I will definitely make it a point to come more often, especially during these summer months when it doesn't get dark until later in the evening.  I like including these Lyon Street steps in a loop walk going that covers some of the nearby steep hills, and also a walk amongst the nice mansions located along Broadway between Divisadero and Lyon.
author: H K.

description:
Partial city view on top (Broadway Street). Presidio hiking trail literally next door.

Good exercise, average to moderate difficulty for fit people.

Park at Green Street (bottom of stairs), climb, then meander back down. Beware steep steps at Vallejo Street. Or park at Broadway Street (top) where spots are aplenty.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Some of the best steps to run in the City, with incredible vistas and plenty of room to pass or be passed. Other top contenders for stairs to run in SF:
- Filbert Street Steps (to Coit Tower)
- Baker Beach Sand Stairs (aka: Sand Ladder)
author: J. R.

description: This is a hidden gem of SF and a must-visit!  Basically, it's a huge staircase that is perfect for tourists and workout junkies alike.  I love to take these steps down to the water.  So gorgeous and great exercise.
author: Ashley K.

description: Another little special place for a good view of part of the city. I can see that it gets busy since the narrowness of the steps. There are often people running up and down to exercise.
author: Lianna D.

description: great views of the bay especially at dusk. hope we had gotten there a little earlier to setup. there is a mix of exercise folks (regulars) and a bunch of visitors. there is never an issue with the regulars. folks living there i envy you and maybe someday will join the likes to live there.
author: Ram S.

description: The absolute best workout you can get for free. The stairs will kick your ass even if you do them once, but the view is so worth all the heavy breathing. Sometimes gets a little crowded but everyone is friendly and keeps out of each others way. Even if you aren't in the mood for a workout- the view and people/house watching is spectacular and shouldnt be missed!
author: A H.

description:
Tassels flapping in the breeze, wind on my face, map in my basket,  tires fully pumped, I took my freshly cleaned bike from the Richmond District, where I live, down California Street, turned left on Presidio and went to the top of the Lyon Street Steps. And I must say; this is not the way to do it! Even if you were an Olympic athlete, this is NOT the route to take; or at very least, take a car.  This small, affluent neighborhood, where housing prices soar into the multi-millions-(the average being 15 mill), and neighbors like Robin Williams, Danielle Steele and Dianne Feinstein walk the streets, is known as Presidio Heights.  She has well earned the Heights part of  her name as I huffed and puffed, struggling to push my bike up her several hills.

Once I arrived, I sprawled out at the top of the steps,trying to keep my heart firmly encased in my chest cavity. After those hills, the Lyon Street steps, located in the Marina/Cow Hollow District, didn't look too menacing. I was to learn (again), don't judge a book by its cover, or in this case a staircase by its steps.

I began at the intersection of Lyon and Pacific Street(s), the elevation is 379 feet, with stunning views of The Palace of Fine Arts and the hills of Marin.  With less than 300 steps, the sensation directly following your awe at the spectacular scenery, is one of vertigo.  379 foot elevation, 288 steps-do the math.  (The other entry point is at Green Street, at a pleasant cul de sac under shade trees.)

The nice thing about the steps is that they are even, concrete, well maintained, and broken up into four (very steep) sections with little cul de sacs, gardens and 'rest' places.  On the other side of the coin, these steps are a prime exercise destination taken over by power walking grannies and sweating exercise fiends.  I went during the week, so the steps were pretty empty, but, I can imagine that on the weekends, they are packed.  These would be like the Santa Monica Stairs or the Thousand Steps in Laguna Beach, both awesome workout spots.

Approximately halfway down (or up) the steps, there is a lovely garden and one of the many 'hearts of San Francisco'.  This is a really great program started in 2004, as a fundraiser for San Francisco General Hospital.  Each year, heart sculptures are painted and installed throughout the city, Union Square, Golden Gate Park, Moscone Center, SFO, etc...  At years end, they are auctioned off and the project begins anew.  This heart, is called the Migrant Heart, and was designed by Hung Liu in 2004.

These are great steps for sights and exercise.  Due to their steepness, I would rate them at a 7 or 8 on a scale of 10.  But then again, I don't like to sweat; I like to meander-so, it really is a matter of perspective.

 For photos and more information, cruise over to our site at: The Noise Beneath the Apple (dot) com.

Cheers!
author: Heather J.

description: Not the first place in SF I'd visit, but if you've already seen all the touristy places, its a great place to checkout. Nice views of the bay
author: Charlie Y.

description: What an unexpected hidden gem! It a very short set of steps to lead up to an entrance to presidio. Nice peaceful view at the top of Alcatraz and the water. There wasnt a lot of ppl when i went. Mostly locals exercising and walking about.
author: Angela L.

description: An amazing source of cardio for those who can't afford a gym membership. Although the obstacle may seem mediocre because "it's only stairs", make no mistake about this one! The incline is definitely a challenge and the steps you climb is definitely tiresome. I try to lunge my way up if I don't run/jog. The houses are so majestical as you work your way to the top. And the view at the peak is the stairs of breath taking! Couldn't of asked for a better scene. Thanks, San Francisco.
author: Kat Z.

description: Beautiful views, beautiful houses and beautiful landscaping. Lyon street steps have become a weekly, if not daily, ritual. It's such a nice feeling exercising in San Francisco's "Beverly Hills." I love running down Broadway, usually spotting Gordon Getty outside his home. He usually mean mugs me (assuming I'm going to rob his wallet or something)
author: Andrew V.

description:
A grueling workout:
Two hundred eighty eight steps
With a nice top view.

No need for a gym.
Lots of masochists climbing,
Up and down, repeat.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Beautiful houses, many cement steps, a San Francisco heart, and a breathtaking view.  

What a lovely way to spend a Saturday morning.  We had brunch on Chestnut and then burned off the calories here (definitely within walking distance if you want to grab a bite/get some energy before attempting the stairs).

The steps are great for a workout, a simple stroll and even a photoshoot (yep! bring your SLR out on a blue-skied San Francisco morning and you'll have a blast not only with the bay in the background, but also the flowers and magnificent homes around you). 

At the top of the steps, there's a trail to the right that leads into the Presidio - if you are so inclined, you could definitely continue the workout from there.
author: Kimya P.

description:
I am giving these steps a three.  Why?  The views?  No...the views are stunning.  The architecture?  No...it's just about perfect.  

The steps get three stars because so many people have decided that they are not meant for private contemplation and enjoyment of the vista, but rather, are, in fact, their outdoor stair master.  

I dislike intensely the boot camp craze in San Francisco and cannot wait for it to pass.  Most of us exercise to stay in shape.  A very small amount of us exercise because they are soldiers and often have to fight for their lives.  If you are a  28 year old management consultant, you do not need to enter a program designed by a navy seal.  Try playing tennis on the weekends instead?

To those new to the stairs, when you visit, do not be surprised when you are jostled by some kid, dying of heat and other forms of exhaustion, as he "sprints" up the stairs.  Perhaps we should station an ambulance there?
author: Steven R.

description:
OUCH! UGH! AWW....WHOA!

Were the only words that filtered outta my mouth as I climbed those steep steps of what I thought was an easy breezy flight up. Nope. Thighs, quads, hams and the works-hurt. But it was a good hurt and most def worth it as I reached the top and was presented with a magnificent view of a chunk of the city. Breath taking, stunning and as usual, reinforces the fact of why I heart SF so much. Seriously, if you want to turn that flab into fab, then do the steps-all 240? 241? I lost count after 240.
author: Laurel P.

description:
Wow.  Just wow.

The Lyon Street Steps have been "bookmarked" forever, and finally on this beautiful January day  I finally made it out there. (I still can't believe I was out in shorts in January- I feel like I was on an episode of Beverly Hills 90210...the old one).  Parking was also plentiful here, but that could have been because it was a weekday.

I think of myself somewhat of a steps connoisseur (actually I think I'm a connoisseur of a lot of things), but as working my booty is a priority of mine and steps are the best way to do that, I've tried a bunch.  These are great because the incline and space between the steps changes.  You want less of a grade?  You do the upper steps.  You want to do what basically amounts to a sprint up the steps?  You do the lower steps.  You want to work yourself so hard that you almost vomit, but because the view and surrounding houses take away your breath in such a way that you can't think about hurling?  You do the whole thing.  More than once.

As I am still recovering from the broken foot, I didn't do as many rounds as I would have liked, but got a decent post-lifting workout anyway.

Just a note:

For how tall I am (relatively so), I'm glad I have little feet.  Those steps on the really steep part are tiny, and as I managed to fall just in my driveway and break my foot, I now have a little PTSD when it comes to falling in general.  Just be careful on those things.
