Also: Thanks to the woman who told those jerks who were SMOKING CIGARETTES  on the bench off.  Who does that where you clearly see people working out?  Why don't you just trip us, too?  Much quicker death if we land properly.  Sheesh.
author: Pam S.

description:
San Francisco is a great city for people who want to work out but don't want to join a gym. Not only is the city full of hills to work your buns but has over 300 stairways to get a maximum workout in minimal time. My six favorite workouts are free and have fabulous views to keep you entertained. 

1. Lyon Street Steps- Start at the corner of Lyon and Green Street and walk or better run up these popular steps all the way to Broadway and back. Great workout. Popular but there's no finger pointing or mocking when you need a break and grasp the handrail gasping for air. 

2. Presidio's Immigrant Point/Coastal Connector better known as the "1000 Steps"- It's actually only 808 steps but its sure to make you feel the burn. The trail starts at Overlook Point and takes you all the way to Baker Beach. Beautiful views and a shady canopy make this a great weekend walk or run. 

3. Coit Tower- The Telegraph Hill walk up to Coit Tower is the most scenic city hike on a clear day. I've had the pleasure of running up to Coit Tower (unintentionally) on the main street and it's a great workout sans steps. You will 100% feel the burn. You can also take the Filbert Street Steps of the Greenwich Street Steps for a more scenic and classic trip up to Coit Tower. Anyway you do it, you'll be sure to appreciate the sweeping views and benches to rest on at the top of the tower. 

4. Crissy Field- For those who desire no incline try walking or running Chrissy Field. This dead flat trail takes you from the Marina/ Fort Point to the foot of the Golden Gate Bridge. A good resting point is the Sports Basement for a drink or restroom break. 

5. Golden Gate Bridge- I attempted to give my mother a heart attack a few years ago when I came up with the fantastic idea to bike across the Golden Gate Bridge. This is a strenuous bike ride which should not be taken lightly. If you aren't into biking the bridge, an easier (and more enjoyable) trip is to walk the bridge or run. The views can't be beat and since you are walking the bridge you get twice the work out as you have to walk back across to the city. 

The City has so many wonderful exercise possibilities. Take advantage of the city's natural topography and get a workout while exploring the city by the bay!
author: Alice S.

description: The Lyon St. Stairs are a gray place to get a workout. Another great thing for the parents is that while you are working out, you children can shout hoops.
author: C B.

description: Close by the Presidio. Pretty easy flight of stairs actually. I need a BIGGER challenge! Hehehehe :)
author: Amy C.

description:
Steps are great. Beautiful view, houses are lovely. Middle garden is very picturesque... For tourists the best view is half way down both the upper steps - allows you to see around the house - and lower steps - for the same reason. 

As a rule of etiquette, please don't bring your dog on a lease for the 80% of the people that use the stairs as a workout there's nothing more frustrating than having to watch out for a chihuahua leash at your feet. Additionally, please understand that it's not nice for either party to have to pass someone on the lower portion of the stairs so timing your start is important if someone is running the stairs slower or more quickly than you are. Enjoy!
author: Andrew B.

description:
When we rolled up, I saw some guy puking in a trash can.  (Don't worry, it was the compost bin.)  That really should have been a clue as to how painful these steps can be.

But you know what they say - the best things require work.  And it's especially true in this case.  The view from the top will make the burning sensation in your lungs and quads worth it.

This is definitely somewhere that everyone should check out, especially if you are looking for a spot to get a workout.

Just remember - aim for the compost bin.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Super great steps, nice views and steep. Not much new to add here that others haven't already said.

Although, some of the Marina workouters are either very rude or just completely oblivious (which honestly, is another form of rude). They walk/pretend to jog slowly with their earphones in and take up the whole width of the stairs (or worse are going the wrong direction). People should be more aware of their surroundings when working out, especially in a public location.

Watch out for tourists on nice afternoons in the summer, they ruin everything if you actually want a decent workout.
author: Ninja R.

description: Finally finally made it to this beautiful place.  I always thought I had to drive over here, but I can see I can leave the car behind and access it through the Presidio Avenue in through the Presidio gate.  There are plenty of others heaving and puffing, but they definitely have been going up and down more than once.  I loved the Heart with the crane sculpture in the middle with the well groomed garden.  How appropriate.  It's like your own backyard and stair climber, but you are actually outdoors breathing in the fresh air.
author: Helen L.

description:
Absolute love.
The first time I made it out to the Steps I got the butt-kicking of my life - this is despite my 4+ years of competitive cross country running.

Now, it's a wonderful way to start a day (or to fit in a quick workout any time of the day).
author: Jessie K.

description: Beautiful! A place to chill and enjoy the sights and views of the bay. It's also a place where you can exercise by doing the stairs. Just an all around gem in SF.
author: Stephen D.

description:
You and I have become like hidden lovers.  You're not exactly close but, actually out of my way when I'm not in the city, yet I have such affinity for you that I will travel your way for a quickie (workout)

I love your view, it reminds me of how amazing SF is.  Stopping randomly for some pilates moves and/or masochistic push-ups also is my definition of fun.

Oh ya, beloved Lyon Street Steps, we will rendezvous again soon.
author: Athena S.

description: One of my favorite places in the city to get a workout in.  Lots of steps and an amazing view.
author: Dilly M.

description:
I run these steps all the time.  It's great to go up and down a few times, run to the hands at the Golden Gate Bridge and back.  Stop off for some push ups and sit ups at the top of the steps.  
Great place to work out, run, and be in your own zone.  The view is amazing.
author: James H.

description: looking down is already good cardio, it'll get your heart racing.
author: Margarita T.

description: The Lyon street steps are hidden but after you climb over 200 steps, you finally reach the main stairs which are surrounded by gardens and beautiful flowers. You can see amazing views of the SF bay and Palace of Fine Arts from this location. Parking was easy along the residential areas and the neighbors are really friendly here. Some even came up to us to chit chat. However, my calves and ankles were hurting for days after we had gone all the way to the top and back down. Definitely stretch if you are going to tackle the Lyon. Funny enough, we had already tackled the Green street steps earlier in the day and my friend and I were already aching. Beautiful flowers align the steps and a beautifully painted heart highlights the garden.
author: Danster L.

description:
The Lyon Street Steps wins for fancy-panciest steps in San Francisco. Park at the top on Broadway in Pacific Heights and work your way down brick steps next to mini Versailles Gardens. Ooh la la! No overgrown bushes and homeless encampments here.

I saw people doing workouts here running and up and down the steps. Oh how I wish I lived in San Francisco so I could do the same.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
A great workout of course, but the best part is that you have the option of continuing your run through the Presidio or Pacific Heights.   Less tourists than the stairs up to Coit Tower and a little safer than the run up Buena Vista Park.  I'm also hoping that by osmosis I can absorb some mojo from the mansions I'm running next to.  

Added bonus is that Liverpool Lil's is just down the block for post run beers.
author: Corey V.

description: One of the best workouts in San Francisco - I believe there are ~250 steps in total, I usually do 4 rounds and then that's enough to completely wipe me out!  There's an incredible view to enjoy while you recover up the top, and as an added bonus there's a San Francisco heart there!
author: Lorna D.

description:
These stairs are located near some of the loveliest homes in SF (my favorite is a grey one on Green St.) and right next to the Presidio.  As you descend, be sure to take a moment to enjoy the view of the Palace of Fine Arts and the Marina district and the flowers along the way.  The stairs and the surrounding landscaped areas are well maintained - a very pretty spot!

Try to come early (if you want to workout) to avoid tourists who want to take pictures on the steps.  While it can get crowded even in the AM (boot camps meet here), at least the early crowd isn't stopping to take pictures.  

If it gets too crowded, there are plenty of steep hills around (such as the one on Baker St.) or run through the Presidio (try Lover's Lane).  

It's surprisingly easy to find free parking (I guess since it's in a residential neighborhood).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Exactly how do drunk people get around that city with so many steps in the way? 

I'd like to thank those stairs for this booty. Thanks.
author: Sahar R.

description: I got engaged here, and she said, "Yes!"  If that doesn't earn 5 stars, I don't know what will!
author: Nathan B.

description: This place inspires me... to work out more.  I'm thoroughly impressed by the  reviewers that had the wherewithal to count the total number of steps.  I would've lost count at 32 as I focused on not keeling over while others (in obviously much better shape) easily darted past.  You'll reach the first flight, only to see that you're only half-way there.  But at the top of the stairs is a reward - beautiful views of the city and easy access to a small part of the Presidio with old trees and lush knolls.  Plus the satisfaction of having a that-much-better physique.
author: Tara C.

description: Took our two year old with us. He finished 1/3 of the stairs and daddy carried him up the hill. We loved it!! The neighborhood is very very nice too. We went back down to the green street from another street that is parallel to the stairs, fun too. It is a great stop on a sunny day. totally worth it.
author: T L.

description:
Second only to running in the eucalyptus grove in the Persidio, I love the lyon street steps. Every time I finish them I feel like I've cheated death and/or am superhuman.  You see, as I approach the top, I'm too afraid I'll trip so I refrain from looking up to see how many steps remain. I keep my head down and keep truckin' hoping the end will suddenly appear. I prefer the second set with the wide/deep stairs that I take two-by-two. 

Everyone doing the stairs is courteous and I never feel like I'm going to get run over on the steps although it can get crowded around 5pm. Gorgeous views of the bay, Pac heights and the Palace of Fine Arts. 

PS Please don't talk on your cell phone and hog the entire staircase--weaving from left to right. It's really hard to get your attention so that I can go around you. k, thanks.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
I always figured being in San Francisco, I would just take advantage of public transportation and walk everywhere -- which would amount to my work out. I haven't felt guilty in a long time, however, my appetite finally caught up with my conscience and I decided to go back to the Lyon street steps. I've only been here one other time, but it tore me up HARD CORE. Since then, I haven't been back.... til today. 

Lovely views, and work out enthusiasts you will find here. As I was slowly ascending up Lyon street to get to the steps, I see Hard core man (HCM). He was descending Lyon street FAST. and backwards may I add... Ok, i'm not intimidated by his intensity. I trudge on. 

There were several people getting a work out in so I decide to join. First set of steps -- not bad. the second set started to worry me. More narrow and steep, I slowly descend... Finally at the bottom. I look up and decide not to look up; just focus on the steps. So I climb up the first set (at the speed of probably 10 on the stair master). I wheezed myself to the top and realize I ascended too fast and my heart feels like its beating out of my chest. I descend again for round 2 anyway.

My second round felt like regret. Nothing but pure regret. I was hurting so bad. HCM whizzes past me at probably the car speed of 7 mph. Ascending the stairs mind you.  

As I catch my breath halfway up again, I look up and see Hard core woman (HCW) descending the stairs -- with baby in hand! Strapped on like a 10 lb weight, both baby and HCW start to ascend up the stairs... pass me up and look at me with pity as she continues onward with ease. I get it, I fail. 

I slowly descend to the bottom and decide after 2 painful rounds for a noob, I feel pretty accomplished. I wait to take the 45 on Lyon and Union and see HCM pass me by running to no end down Lyon. What are you ON, man?
author: Maureen B.

description: I got there early morning on Labor Day-unfortunately the views were not very good as the fog was still burning off. There were about 15 people total in the area but the stairs are long enough for people to pass if necessary.  As others have mentioned the lower steps are rather treacherous.  There was morning dew and I could envision myself taking a header on the way down.  Thankfully not, however!  I agree that they are much steeper and narrower than the top sections.  I was actually getting a bit dizzy trying to make sure I hit each one.  Great workout, I only got 3 sets done and my calves are feeling it today.  Going back again.
author: Teri X.

description: Whether you are walking this or running this, you have the heart of a champion. The incline on these steps as well as the hills in the surrounding neighborhood is what I love. Your thighs and tones buttocks will hate you afterwards but after the pain is gone you'll feel fabulous! I always come here to clear my mind or train for an upcoming race.
author: Leslie L.

description: Totally worth it.  Was a bit scared by the reviews, but still decided to go and check it out.  The stairs were not too bad, and the best part is there's a side entrance to the Presidio at the top of the steps!!!  Such a nice neighborhood to walk around!!!
author: Tiffany H.

description: Beautiful spot to add a little spice to your run.  Really cool view at the top.
author: David P.

description:
I know the cure for a bunch of crullers from All Star - and that is the Lyon (I Am The Pleasure and I Am The Pain) Street Steps.  1200 steps later and I feel, well...terrible, but in a good way. 

This is a very special place in SF. Karma need a little nudge? Come here. Beautiful scenery, incredible landscaping, happy people and a great work out. Or, don't work out and just hang out at the top or in the middle.

This is a total 5 star place. 

I know I rate a lot of 5s - I don't like to go to places that suck.
author: J T.

description:
Love these steps!

I have a very much love-hate relationship with them, but in the end, I really love them.

Start off with a warm up going up Lyon street from Lombard, then it's up these gorgeous steps, pausing to do 10 push-ups at every block.  Repeat on way down.  3 sets of stairs and about 30 minutes later, you've done 120 push-ups and went up and back down 864 steps (288 stairs, each direction).

Great workout that I recommend to everybody.  I'm going again tomorrow!

Oh yeah, this also just happens to be the absolute best butt workout in the city so you know they will be lots of cuties running here. :)
author: Pavel B.

description:
Workout boredom making you want to throw in the towel?

Stop counting minutes and start counting stairs !!

Stair running is an intense, high impact cardiovascular workout guaranteed to work you into shape. Just 30 minutes on the stairs should be plenty to get you sweating. And in San Francisco you have the opportunity to stair climb through the best possible scenery, allowing for an amazing mental and physical workout. The Lyon Street Steps are the perfect place to start  - the unintimidating stair series will help you become a serious stepper in no time! Here's to getting your rear into gear!

A few things to keep in mind before you start sweating......

**Make sure to WARM UP with some light jogging, quadricep/calf stretches, and a few flights of stairs at an easy pace.  

**Bring water - stay hydrated before, during, and after your workout.

**Always wear good running shoes - stair running can be really hard on your joints and you'll want to keep your knees/ankles/hips happy.

**Make sure to watch your foot/knee alignment as you step, placing the full foot on the step and keeping the knees behind toes. 

**End your workout with a solid cooldown that includes walking, hamstring, quadriceps, and calf stretches. 

Take a step in a new direction and rediscover the fun in fitness with some scenic San Francisco stair workouts! Enjoy!
author: Caroline J.

description:
If anything is going to get me through the end of a 4.5 year relationship, it's these stairs. Seriously, nothing clears my mind like listening to a little Black Eyed Peas or Ratatat and charging up these babies with my fellow sado masochists. 

If anything is going to make me projectile vomit at the top of the 15th flight of stairs, it's going to be that couple swapping spit like it's the 8th grade winter formal. Seriously, take it somewhere else, can't you see I am trying to mend my broken heart by beating my ass, thighs, and calves into submission? I'd rather not be forced to watch you playing tonsil hockey at the end of each set. 

New rule: gorgeous view reserved for those here to exercise only. And no, your tongue doesn't count.
author: Rachael S.

description:
When you are in the mood for a butt burning, vertigo inducing workout, the Lyon St. Steps are where you need to head! I try to incorporate the steps into a workout at least twice a week. A few laps up and down the section just South of Vallejo will make even the fittest people break a good sweat. When you need a breather, the view of the Bay from the top of the steps on Broadway is spectacular.
I also think that the steps are the easiest walking route to/from the Marina if you live in Pac. Hts./Laurel Hts. It is much easier to walk the stairs than steep sidewalks!
author: Bobby J.

description:
Does it get any better than the huff/puff from Marina green all the way up to Green St., that slight incline never subsides and you feel yourself deflate at the site of the "Lyon St. stairs"....
I had no idea these even existed, I was in so much awe over the beautiful homes I was running passed on Green and Broadway that I almost missed the stairs completely. 
I ran, well almost ran, up them once and felt like my legs were going to fall off. There are four sections so when you complete each one you have to coax yourself to finish the next. 
I will be back to those stairs soon and my new goal will be to make it to the top without a walk break!
Oh, and might I add that once you finish each section  you can see different sections of the Bay, and at the top- well, I'll let you decide what kind of view that is... :)
author: Janell D.

description:
While training for a marathon, you are often told you have to "earn it." The same goes for the Lyon Street Steps.

Even if you rock the eliptical, dominate the treadmill, or kill it in spin class.... Lyon Street Steps WILL own you.Moving your own body weight without assistance up these steep steps will make you regret every cocktail you had over the weekend and vow to give up baked goods.  You will wonder to yourself why nobody else is panting as hard as you and wonder if it's healthy for your heart to beat that fast. Luckily, in just a few visits your cardiovascular capacity, and tush, will undergo a major transformation.
author: Rachael W.

description: Great view and a ton of steps--great for a grusome workout!  It was a pretty cold day today but the work-out will make you sweat.
author: Wendy T.

description:
292 of the best damn breakup-therapy steps ever. Period.

OK. I originally wrote that a long time ago. And it's still true. They work. But these stairs continue to deliver long after your heart has mended. Don't let your ex own these steps! Reclaim them for yourself get your booty climbing. And descending. Repeat...
author: kai k.

description:
We took the day off. It was my birthday after all. What better way to spend it than running around the city like tourists, but only picking out the really cool spots to visit. The sun was out, and the sky was a beautiful blue. And for the first time in the lifetime that I've lived in San Francisco, I scaled the Lyon Street Steps. First, down. Then, up. What spectacular views, leaving me breathless. 

Oh wait, no. 

That would be me climbing up all these stairs. Correction: Huffing and puffing up all these stairs. It's no wonder that so many include the Lyon Street Steps as part of their workout routine.

Your muscles ache. Your breath is drawn. You appreciate this city, this life, and this staircase that they thankfully built handrails for.
author: Tinna H.

description:
The Lyon steps are a awesome workout!!!
Can't beat the view, the beautiful homes, the well manicured gardens and the the sweat!!!
make sure you take a bottle of water. have a sip or two and just keep on going!!!
author: karla m.

description:
I used to walk these stairs on the regular.  i was skinnier then.  that was cool.  the only way to get my less fat ass up and down these stairs is by listening to hard core rap music because not only do i really, really want to be black but also, lil' kim makes me seriously want to MURDER these stairs.  i'd have my ipod on, huffing and puffing my way up the STAIRS OF DEATH, listening to lil' kim yell at big poppa about him still being married when she's all fucking him and she'll always love him and shit.  LOVE IT.  i hope to one day be in such a violent yet truly caring relationship of insanity...i might be in one right now with my mom but i think that's a little different.  

when i felt especially sassy, i would sing along to my hard core rap music much to the chagrin of the chicks from the marina who were listening to matchbox 50 and bouncing quarters off of their lulu lemon asses.  I would barely be able to breathe, grandmas in wheelchairs passing me, head down, concentrating on just getting up the next step, singing out:

All I wanna do is get my pussy sucked 
Count a million bucks in the back of an armor truck
While I get you fucked up off the T.O.N.Y.
The BX, the chron-chron
And the list goes on and on

I seriously fucking love lil' kim because NOBODY does hyper sexual scorned woman like that bitch...she should do an album with Loretta Lynn, those bitches could commiserate and be all super dirty sexy together and it would RULE.

Finally, bring tourists here for the amazing view.
author: Laura B.

description:
There are so many paths in life, it's sometimes difficult finding the proper one.

Some paths are easier than others, meandering on slight inclines that comfortably rest at happy elevations. Life is gentle and quiet, and you're left relatively undisturbed in the mix. But then there are those much steeper, hidden roads requiring inspiration or guidance from a muse, where hard work and perseverance ultimately rewards itself through glorious views. And eventually you reach that point in your life when you finally feel in control, standing at the top with an absence of fear, where strange surprises only add spice to the already well-paved path... where the sun shines brighter and colors pop and the horizon is beautiful...

No one's going to take me alive.
author: Keane L.

description:
Really love these stairs! You get a great view of the city and a killer workout!

If you're like me and people are blowing by you-- don't be discouraged, go at your own pace. Start at the very bottom... the stairs are a little more steep and work your way up to the top. When you get there you'll get a view of the Bay as you catch your breath. Then, go down and do it all over again. What's better than an awesome view while working out? 

Forget about paying for your gym membership... this is the best part about it, it's free! :)
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Great place to chow down on a jumbo bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast burrito in a hungover stupor while watching blond-highlighted, iPod armband-wearing Marinaites bound up the 288 concrete stairs in their tightass yoga pants and drool over the greasy contents of your tinfoil wrap each of the eight times they run by.

If you do manage to make it to Broadway, be sure to check out the 12-foot anatomically disproportionate robot sculpture stationed outside one of the mansions east of The Steps.  Gotta love 90's art!
author: Erin L.

description:
Look at all my 5 star fellows... It is the endorphins, I tell ya!

I think about quitting my gym membership because of these stairs! It is one of my favorite SF discoveries. When I make it to the top for my 5th set. I look out across the bay and think how lucky I am before I DIE from exhaustion.

Come here if you want a solid work out. Great for cardio and strengthening the gluts. While running the stairs, make sure you pick up the rear, for your ass will be the focal point of your followers. Although it does get your butt up to the top quicker when you feel the eyes piercing your buttocks.

It's a great experience. I will continue to run here till I have no legs.
author: Dee C.

description:
The trick to doing these stairs as a workout is to slide down on the railings on the top half on the way down (it's too steep on the bottom half). I mean, if you're not having fun, what's the point? Plus, it shocks and surprises the pac-heights / marina stepford wives / wives-to-be, the dogs get all excited, and the tourists' kids start to pull away from the their parents to try it themselves.
Although I'm sure I have a blackish stripe going diagonally across the ass of my pants.

Five to ten roundtrips is an acceptable aerobic workout for the day. Anything less and you're a candy ass.
Curbside, liverpool lils, and pres a vi are waiting a short distance from the bottom for your post-workout patronage. (presidio social club as well on Saturdays)
author: Bob R.

description:
My story of "The Steps" . . . .
A few years back I officiated a wedding right on the steps  - Yes, Presbyterian pastors can be Yelpers too! ;-)  You can't really get a permit to do such things so we all just invaded the steps around the flowers and had the wedding.  Limo pulls up, the wedding party in full dress bounds out, the guests had already arrived and a find young minister in a very sheik black robe conducted the ceremony complete with gawking joggers.   What were the cops going to do?  There were about 30 of us, clearly a classy dressed up wedding party and, come on, it was a wedding. 
Quite the site and quite the memory!
author: Bruce R.

description:
Soo....people run up these stairs? Too MANY stairs, people. I don't even like walking up the two flights of stairs to my flat. And you get some sort of joy by the calf muscle burnage? I will stick to cycling for that.

Suit yourselves, though.

Maybe throw the Rocky theme song on the iPod and be like Rosie F?  When you get to the top in your gray jumpsuit, you can pump your fists at the sky and pretend like you're king/queen of the world...

My general dislike of running aside, this is an amazing spot to visit.

I imagine that I could sit on the steps and soul search here, maybe write in the journal for awhile. Or I could be taken here by a lovely woman...we could stare off towards the Palace of Fine Arts & the San Francisco bay, lights flickering  & the sound of the foghorn blowing in the distance. 

(i only dislike running because my ankles are so jacked from skateboarding when i was younger)
author: matt m.

description:
Foggy-headed and more than a little confused when the phone rang, I barely had enough time to check the time before answering her call.  9:45am.  With a slight sense of alarm I forced a cheery, sleep-heavy "Hello!".  She apologized for being late and that they'd be there as soon as possible.  Where was I, she asked?  Mortified, I told her I didn't think we were still on for our Lyon Street Steps run because of the email confusion.  It was still on, she confirmed cheerily!  After hanging up I jumped out of bed, pulled on some athletic gear and was searching for a clean pair of socks when I got her second call; They were downstairs, should they park and come up or wait for me?  30 seconds and I'd be down, I told her.

It was brrrrr-worthy outside, a chilling breeze sweeping over Nob Hill, with a few Lycra-clad cardio champs braving the endless flights of steps.  Going down the steps was easy.  Climbing back up was another story.  Halfway up the fourth flight of stairs I was winded!  We ran it three times before our other friend cheerily ran us through a couple more drills.  At the top of the steps we took in the beautiful view of the Palace of Fine Arts.

A great way to start off the morning, and a superb butt-shaping workout for sure!
author: Janet L.

description: I love running the Lyon Street Steps! They are always a challenge, no matter how fit you are. Extra props for those who do the bottom half - it is much harder.
author: Michelle T.

description:
all the workout stuff aside...

one can walk through here feeling as though you're on the property of some of san franciscos most pricey estates. you can expect (as im sure you can imagine from reading the other reviews) a ton of joggers/step climbers during the day and even a few at night and then the high-school kids on weekend/friday nights hanging out drinking and smoking pot. some adults even.

but what we all mostly come here for is the views. a stunning look at everything from the lush presidio to the golden gate bridge to alcatraz. its all there. now to be honest if you're just a tourist visiting the city i wouldn't go out of my way to go check this place out. There's too many other better things to see if you're just in town for a short stay. but if you have a plethora of spare time this is a great spot to check out.

and runners/step climbers... believe me. this place WILL kick your ass.
author: Andrew D.

description:
The scene: Friday night, October 28, 1999. 

The characters: Uni High Preps, Urban Art Fucks, Branson Jocks, and the occasional SDI.

The plot: Fourties in hand, braving the cold, wanting to be 21. Taking the last drag of a cigarette. Running from HMI.

The outcome: Still love Mickeys.
author: Sam S.

description:
This is the best outdoor workout in the city.  If you have 30 minutes, you will get a great cardio workout and be inspired by the views.

This is actually two sets of stairs.  The bottom set (starts at Green St) is far steeper with only one landing break.  There are 124 steps (62 in each section) on the bottom set (give or take a few - hard to keep track when my heart is racing).

The second set goes up to Billionaire Row (I believe the top is Broadway).  The second set is not nearly as steep and has landings every 20 or so steps.  

Descending the top set is a piece of cake - really really fast with great views.  Now the lower set is a different story.  The first descent is easy, but after a few trips, the legs are a bit wobbly and shakey. The lower set is both steeper and the steps are narrower.

I can usually do 5 full round-trips in about 25 minutes which is about all I can muster.
author: Madison W.

description:
I do not need a personal trainer - I just need a commute that includes the Lyon Street stairs...2 or 3 times a day.

These lovely and grueling steps were the second stop on my evil training plan when I was training myself and several poor souls for the Avon Walk.  After walking my little ducklings through Fort Mason and the Marina, I turned to these stairs as a way to build stamina for the 39 mile/2 day walk.  Huffing, puffing, and hating my guts (even I hated my guts), we pulled up to the top of the grand staircase before heading, mercifully, back downhill on Broadway.

Funny thing - I never noticed the beauty or really even the view until long after those crazy training days.  The steps, built in 1916, were placed because the grade was too steep for a road.  From the bottom, hidden in a cul-de-sac next to a deeply forested section of the Presidio, to the top with it's peerless views of the bay and the Marina, these stairs should be known as much for their landscaped beauty (who is the gardener?!?) as for their ability to give us Beyonce's booty.
author: Suzanne B.

description: Almost 300 steps, surrounded by spectacular homes and the lush green of the Presidio. My #1 spot to sweat when I'm in the city!
author: Trip C.

description:
I was proudly telling my friends and colleagues that I began 2007 here at the bottom of Lyon Street steps.  Then just now it hit me that I didn't have to limit my reach and could brag to a much wider audience if I yelped about it.   So....  yep...that's right.... I included Lyon Street steps on my New Year's day run! 

I do not usually run these steps as Coit/Filbert Street steps are included in my weekly Wednesday am run.. but have to say that Lyon street stairs definitely can hold a match.  

In comparing the two I would say that the beautiful views at top are equivalent although the Coit tower view is more panoramic.  Coit steps are not as steep so you glutes don't get ass much of a work-out (yes that corny pun was totally intentional).
author: Kerrie T.

description:
A free outdoor StairMaster with a beautiful view - brilliant

Though be careful on the lower flight of the stairs, they are much more shallow then the upper level and as your calves and quads start to scream at you, a mis-step may cause one to tumble, thankfully there is a handrail.
author: Sarah B.

description:
Gorgeous view. I always forget how awesome the marina is in terms of the view from the hill. Normally I just think bleach blondes and stripped shirts.

I think I am going to have to start running these steps. Part of the "get fit or dry trying in 2009" plan, similar to the foiled plans of 2008. But I didn't know about these stairs then. That will be my excuse. That and I spent my time getting laid by someone who doesn't want to date me this year.

Change in 09!
author: Alexis B.

description: For the quintessential Pacific Heights experience, and one of the best photo ops in the city, situate yourself at the top of these steps located between the Presidio and some magnificent mansions for a panoramic view of the Bay, the Marina, and the Palace of Fine Arts. Then descend them to marvel at the homes and the impeccably manicured gardens that border them. Just remember it's a long, steep climb back to the car you left parked at the top.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
A must stop bi-weekly circuit for everyone to enjoy and the exact reason why I never-ever go to the gym.  

With these views and those endorphin's, you won't feel the bitter-sweet sting of the jog for the whole way home.
author: Yelper A.

description:
Ok, did you say a BUTT workout??? If that's what you;re looking for, DO IT!! 

When you reached the TOP, that's your prize! I beautiful view!!
author: Judi K.

description: I wanted to puke, my head was spinning, and I swear they almost killed me.  Can't wait to run them again.
author: Amie W.

description:
Sunday mornings this is where you will find me workin off all that fun I had over the weekend. Running steps is the best because you can't stop halfway, you gotta get up or down...ie: too bad lazy ass. The Lyon steps border between being a semi-social place to check out fit young-ish people and an insane workout that will get you sweating hard.

Ipod necessary.

Only problem is they can sometimes get crowded (especially when people bring dogs).

Scenic. Tough. Satisfying. Booyakasha!
author: Alison D.

description:
StairMasters are for wimps...the real thing is so much better!  This is one of my favorite places to work out.  The pretty views distract from the pain!  If you're here in the wee hours of the morning like I am, wear bug spray.  The mosquitos are vicious and will bite right through your clothes.

9/07 update: I've noticed that there's usually a security guard here in the evenings, patrolling in front of what I think is Di Fi's house.  Works for me -- this must be one of the safest places to work out outside in the evenings, especially now that the days are getting shorter!
author: DD B.

description: A gem in SF - a hidden place to take visitors when you have done enough trips to Crooked Street.  Weekend workout groups tend to clog the top of the stairs but oh well - it adds to the atmosphere...
author: Ash A.

description:
An absolutely stunning San Francisco landmark, yet like so many of our stairways, totally ignored by the tourists.  I guess if you can't drive on it, it's not interesting.  Last time I was here a car full of people pulled up right at the top of the steps and asked me how to get to Lombard St ("you know, the curvy part"), totally oblivious of the even better attraction right below them.  Impressed by my knowledge of local geography, they then wanted to know where The Sweetest Thing was filmed.  Sorry folks, I deleted that movie from my memory.  Don't you want to know where Jimmy Stewart and Kim Novak went?

Anyhoo, the steps have it all: views of the bay, the Palace of Fine Arts, lavish Pacific Heights mansions (including Dianne Feinstein's house), beautifully sculpted gardens, a somewhat under-utilized adjacency to the Presidio, and of course 50 copies of the same 27-year-old woman in extremely fashionable (and tight) sports outfits running up and down while listening to God knows what on their ipods.  

It's also the perfect spot for a Saturday afternoon prelude-to-a-night-out rendezvous with your friends--one of those SF places where the infinite possibilities of a weekend in the city really become palpable, and you feel ready to go anywhere and do anything.
author: Wes M.

description:
Jane Fonda would love it here!! 
It's the best staircase in the city, no doubt. 
I only wish there was better lighting at night (especially during winter) F'ing daylight savings.

Sometimes there's lines of people running up & down the Lyon St stairs with a timer at the top. very serious! it's the place to go for a focused quad/calf workout!...And if you wear a neon sweat-band and spandex, you'll burn more calories!!! 
'Get-In-Shape Girl!'
author: Nicole L.

description:
huff, huff.. I can't breathe! 
Come on ..you're doing a good job.. 

That was my conversation this morning while I ran up the stairs with Bay Area Boot camp.

I'm a San Francisco native and I don't recall ever visiting this area. I'm glad I finally did! I can't comment on the view too much because it was still dark out - 6am class. but I can definitely recommend this place if you're looking for a killer work out. 

Unfortunately we only visit this location once with my 4-week class but I promise to rotate this into my workout from now on. The stairs nearly killed me but when it was all over it truly was worth it.  

Buns of steel!!
author: Monica S.

description:
I climbed the Lyon St steps after reading some of your reviews here. I moved to SF about a month ago, and I am having a great time exploring the city on weekends. I live in Sunset, so I am always venturing out in search of the sunshine, and I found this area to be bright and lovely. The gorgeous homes with their beautiful flowers surrounding the entries and colorful gardens made this outing worth it for me, even before I climbed the steps and the vista unfolded before me. 

I will definitely be going back to Lyon St for the climb and the view. Both were awesome.

Filbert St steps are also great fun. Maybe there is a posting about them on here somewhere--I am also new to Yelp, so I'm still finding my way around. The steps at Filbert st are not the wide, concrete type of steps like Lyon St has, they are narrow, winding, and crazy. I have done them twice, both times on vacations--the first year, I started at the bottom and did the big climb, the second encounter I took the bus to the top and walked down. :)  One of these times, someone was trying to move out of their apt carrying a big mattress down all those (single file) steps. Here there are also many flowers and nice homes. It's a very different experience than Lyon st.
author: Java G.

description:
If you're feeling especially ambitious/psychotic, as a few guys and gals I knew were this morning, you could engage in The Physical Challenge.

What? 10am, Sunday. Chug 1 beer, run up the steps. Repeat 4-5 times. Any throwing up=1 more round of steps. 

Not enough for you? Try The Ultimate Physical Challenge. Start off in Aquatic Park, no wetsuits allowed. Chug a beer, jump in, do a lap to the buoy. Chug a beer. Run along the Marina Green to Safeway. Chug a beer. Run to the Palace of Fine Arts (beer), run to Lyon Steps and do intervals of beer and steps.

Though I was a referee, and not a participant, I found this challenge difficult to watch but very memorable to say the least. 

Only in San Francisco.

Bring a positive attitude.
author: Laura D.

description:
In lyon street area, steps run you!

...or at least it seems that way. What better way to work up a sweat on a grueling climb than exquisitely manicured gardens.

Just watch out for those wedding picture parties. Kevin and Stacy- my appologies for the hairy shirtless running guy in the background of that last pic on that very special day in June- you know the one with angel island in it? I'll photoshop it for free, promise!
author: Tim V.

description:
Urban Running at its Best!! This is my new favorite spot to run to. Run up/down the steps, past the palace of fine arts and to Chrissy Field then to the the bridge -- on a clear day there is not a better urban run than this.

Last time I ran here there was a protest going on.  cool!!
author: Megan S.

description:
A breath-taking view of the bay on a beautiful day!!!

=)
author: DAVID N.

description:
I've been here only once in the daytime, but wow I was impressed. The view is amazing, the houses all over this neighborhood are stunning, and the flowers surrounding the steps are beautiful. 

These steps would be a lovely date spot!! I definitely want my future man to take me here. Yum!
author: Bets Y.

description: Stick a fork in my I'm done....These stairs kicked my butt. Usually I'm just staring down the steps laughing at all the people huffing and puffing as they are coming up. So when my friend asked me if I wanted to run up the stairs instead of going to the gym I thought suuuurrreee, why not? Half way up when I was holding back the reflex to vomit I realized that maybe these stair were a little harder then I had imagined. Needless to say, it was a great workout and the next day I cried every time I had to get out of bed for a drink of water.
author: Michele H.

description: There's nothing better than ripping my calves and quads with all those killer views..who needs an iPod when you get the views..An avid rower who's wicked rowing coaches makes us do those stairs on Saturdays...I guess i'll be ready to go Brazilian pretty soon
author: Victoria M.

description: I used to take first dates here before the evening starts. It's a pre qualifier, if you will. The catch is they have execute this run up these stairs in their same little black skirt and heals they showed up in at my door. If the time allotted for the two iterations is met, she is good to go. Second test: No more than 30 minutes get showered, "vixened" up, out the door, and then off to dinner we go. I know it is San Francisco, but doors to be opened by the man...no exceptions. Chivalry is not dead, nor cheesy on my watch, little lady.
author: Michael G.

description: I want to climb them more often!  ..not many steps people will say that about! Could someone be nice enough to give me one of the $10M homes near here? please ;)
author: P H I L H.

description:
This can be a great warm up, final push and/or complete work out!
Dont cheat go ALL the way down (even the steep part) and then all the way back up..dont even stop for the spectacular view half way up..unless you need to catch your breath..
Anyway-I come here to work out (when im sick of the gym) and sometimes bring my dogs to the top just to sit and take it all in..makes me proud to call san francisco home
author: CadoBaby P.

description: San Francisco's version of the Santa Monica stairs.  Great workout and amazing views (if you're not too tired/sore to enjoy them afterwards).
author: Sean H.

description:
I somehow ended up here on a Saturday morning at 10am with a hangover, wearing a ball gown, and smiling for the camera. Don't ask me how, but, trust me, it happened.
It's so beautiful up there... truly a serene, fresh and invigorating environment for your morning run.

But forget that, it's "see and be seen" in your tight running shorts with your cute, tight, butt trailing in your wake. Try flirting with the rich locals; please tell me how it goes?
author: Tina J.

description: Wonderful workout if you like stairclimbing. What is there, about 400 steps here? Not sure.  Great neighborhood!
author: Darrell R.

description: Love the well manicured gardens here!  Always healthy and green.  I read in the Chron that Sen. Feinstein's gardeners "accidentally" tore down the gardens.  Poo.. they are in the works of replacing it.  One of the few hidden gems in SF.  The Lyon Street Steps have one of the most breath taking views of the bay, the Palace of Fine Arts, and Sausilito.  Only the most grandest SF elites manage to score a mansion alongside the steps.  They in itself are a marvel to look at.  This is a great place to show off SF to visitors.  Of course, it's great to work out with or just sit on a cement bench and reflect.
author: Chris T.

description:
Just got my ass kicked here recently... and it was great!

Ran all the way up and took in a gorgeous view of the bay & then took off through the convenient Presidio trail that's just off the top of the stairs.

What a good workout! My body took quite the beating, but it was just what it needed. I'll be back next week!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
I cant believe I have not written a review of one of absolute favorite spots in the city until now!
Great place to get your butt in shape and meditate on how lucky you are to be doing so in such a setting.  
On a sunny day, this is the place that makes you proud to call San Francisco home.
author: Nilu r.

description: Spectacular! What grandeur. This neighborhood is beautiful. Well worth the hike up the steps. Look down on the Palace of Fine Arts. It is a great workout. I will make this a regular destination when I come to the city.
author: Jeromy W.

description:
I'm embarrassed to admit that not only am I a Bay Area native, but I've been a bonafide resident of Pac Heights for over 2 years... and I've ONLY just discovered Lyon Street Steps. 

Where have I been?! Gorgeous. Gorgeous. Gorgeous. Especially at 6:30am when the sun is rising over the city. 

Of course, it was gorgeous all the way until the 8th or 10th or so time I went from bottom to top and started to feel dizzy, my thighs started to quiver, and I was gasping for air... 

But I survived and can't wait to go back as part of my regular workout program.
author: lily l.

description:
Great workout, killer view (or was it great view & killer workout??)

Even just walking these babies will tire you out (and running them will make your legs wobbly). But its worth it for the incredible view of the bay and gorgeous houses all around. Definitely one of my favorite scenic spots in the city.
author: Jessica L.

description:
Used to live in the area and came here occasionally for exercise but wasn't super into doing the lap thing. Why? Because I'm really not that into running DOWN stairs. At least to me, it's kind of a waste of time and it hurts my legs. And I don't like being that close to other people power huffing it. The stairs are a bit narrow. And maybe I just always had the luck of being there when jocky douches were around. Lastly, I've been when strange drug? deals were going down nearby. I don't even know what to say about that. But that is DEFINITELY not my steez. 

That said, it is a nice place to pass through. And if you enjoying running laps on stairs.
author: JJ W.

description:
I walked down these steps many times when I used to work down at the Presidio. I arrived sweaty but having a sense that I somehow achieved something beyond getting to work. 

Even the bitchy looking gals running in their expensive "See Jane Run" outfits seemed endearing...as they gave me dirty looks because I was on *their* way. 

Yes, the views are amazing - as someone previously said, this may be the most "picaresque" area of town! I think she means "picturesque", unless there is something I don't know going on inside those mansions.

Next time I walk down those steps I'll picture socialites in boas, garters and strap-ons dancing to Lady Marmalade.
author: Raul A.

description:
This is a fantastic place to get a fantastic workout! I took one of my personal training clients here a few Fridays ago and now she wants to have a session there once a week! If you pace yourself,  you can have a very rewarding workout. If you don't pace yourself, you could end up puking for fainting halfway up!
The workout: 
Run up the steepest part (2 flights), 10 seconds break in the middle. At the top: push-ups, sit-ups, vertical jumps, frogs, quick alternating lunges, squatting side shuffle, sun salutations. All of this x 4!
It was hard, but she had fun!
I definitely recommend this place for a heart-pumping workout!
author: Keely G.

description: The Lyons Street Steps definitely OWNED me! It was simply stunning and treacherous all at once. Great exercis to include in your workout regimen.
author: Hazel T.

description:
Still aching from last Friday.  These steps are killer.  And yes it is beautiful and yes the butt looks better.
But watch out for the yellow jackets.  Those sons of bitches are in effect, as are the mosquitos.  You have been warned.
author: Pamela D.

description:
Lyon Street Steps show you whos boss. If you're not in the Marina and want some steep steps try the ones up to Twin Peaks off of Corbet in the Castr. They are nice and steep and its a little like running though a tunnel in parts. Cute houses up there too.

I would also have given 5 stars if there was adequate night time lighting.
author: A W.

description:
Pretty. Free. Kicked my ass. The ass the got kicked is now firmer.
See how long I can keep coming here. Hopefully at least 5 times a week.
author: Kokoro I.

description:
There are "spots" throughout SF, which remain absent on most maps, but the most "San Franciscans" know to check out. Lyon street steps is one of those places. 

As a teenager, this was the place to go to grab a drink, sit, and enjoy the gorgeous view. Now older, I'd suggest these steps as a place to read, or just take a stroll. 

It's right next to JFK park, so you can combine the two for a great day of outdoor fun.

SFCritic
author: David J.

description:
The cheapest gym in town, this is the SF equivalent of LA's Santa Monica Steps.

A pleasing mix of the over and under aerobicized, everyone's friendly and parking is easy, but I liked the old Garden setup a lot better than the new one.

My personal record?  10 times!
author: Victoria B.

description:
I'm not sure how anyone can not give a free, beautiful, secret garden five stars! It's such a little treasure hiding right in the middle of the city. And so clean and well cared for. Kudos to the wonderful neighborhood that keeps this garden great!

And to the reviewer who gave this little park one star, because the police called her out on her public drinking: I'm giving you one star for being ridiculously lame. Go drink your forty and make-out somewhere else.
author: Elina R.

description: First time up and down these steps... I like going up better then down. I keep feeling like I'm going to trip and hurdle my way down to the bottom of the stairs with head concussion and everything. The scenery was great, and decorations were amazing. A lot of people were there climbing up/down the stairs and there were little set ups of workout stations. I would definitely do it again. Felt like a safe place to go, as a woman working out alone.
author: Maria C.

description: Want to know what a heart attack feels like? Run up these bad boys 4 times. I was done the first time around but I kept going and my heart was pounding hard. BUT I loved ever minute of it! Your body hates you after this but the reward of knowing you did it and finished what you set out to do out weighs all the pain and suffering. Good workout. Be brave. Have fun.
author: Mel P.

description:
you didn't intimidate me one bit, lyon street steps.  
i overheard your scoffing and snickering.
'...hah.  w/her burger-burrito-hot dog eating tendencies??  she'll never get a workout out of me.'
...

four rounds of climbing later, i haughtily smiled and flexed my butt cheeks in your face.
author: Ting A.

description:
Wear mosquito repellent and be prepared to not walk normally for 2 days if you are a newbie! When I say not being able to walk normally, I mean, strangers on the street thought I was recovering from an accident, I had to walk up stairs and down SIDEWAYS for 2 days.

So pretty though, and you can wave hello to Diane Feinstein, or at least the exterior of her manse on your ups and downs.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I get off the 45 thinking I'll just walk a few blocks to the 43.

A few minutes later I find myself surrounded by sick mansions with amazing roof gardens and a 1000 steps awaiting my accent.

If I had a few million to throw around I'd totally get a house here.  But for now I'll stick with renting a place in a neighborhood where burn-outs shit on the sidewalk, ask for money and try to sell you weed.

--

Oh yeah, and it's not possible to walk from the 45 to the 43 in less than 20 minutes.
author: L J.

description: Huff and puff. The views at the top and the ridiculously amazing houses make a good carrot at the end of the stick. I always bring out of towners here too just to enjoy the area and they are invariably awed.
author: Dan C.

description:
I was running hills one day (when do I not run hills in SF?) and came across lots of series of stairs.  Perfect, I thought, to add to my workout.  It kicked me in the butt!  There are plenty of stairs to get a super workout.  

Just be careful when they are wet and slippery.  Going down steep hills can be challenging.
author: Julie R.

description:
I hate these steps, and I love these steps.  It is a true love/hate relationship.  I look forward to running them all day long, then hate them when I'm there, then love them when I'm finished.  Bring water with you if you're going to run them multiple times.

Amazing workout!
author: Christina N.

description:
I feel a bit dreamy whenever I come here. 

I have only came here to bring people from out-of-town, and normally during sunset. I like to park on the ground to slowly climb up, and then start glancing back to unveil the views, and re-discovering a new set of stairs ahead.

As soon as we climb a few steps, I start dissolving myself into my own world of imagination, as the views progress, and the sun sets. 

I dream of becoming a philosopher, trying to draw analogies from the views and the experience.
I dream of having one of the mansions someday, and sitting at the corner room overlooking the city and the bay beyond.

.....and many many other dreams..............
author: Andy W.

description:
Two hits to get the head straight.  Start from the bottom, where the steps are narrow.  One at a time from here, bust it up to the mid level, stall across, then two at a time up to Broadway, turn around, gassed, mind blowing view, then take it down fast, step slalom, quick turnaround, now nine more times.

Ten years later, when the kids were young and needed the drive for nap time, park at mid-level and let 'em sleep, check on them on the way up and down  - 50 minutes is plenty, early live DMB, Under the Table and Dreaming.

A few years after that, they are strung along the steps giggling and spinning like pinwheels on the landings, no running now, they need to be watched  -  the view is heart-stopping.

Twenty four years later.  Knees can't take  the slalom down any more, but up is still good.  The view never ceases to stun, its a perfect location to break up the commute with an 800 calorie gut buster.  This never gets old and has to be one of the best places in the world.  Check it out, it lasts a looonnnggg time.
author: David T.

description:
I used to live near here and never appreciated it till I moved.
The view is great, just be sure to bring some water :)

I rode my bike down these stairs once, amazingly I'm still intact.
author: Tom S.

description:
Its a Love/Hate Relationship.  

Amazing view at the top....enough to make you forget how much you hate them while running up.

The Love prevails as I continue to incorporate the stairs into my training schedule.  How can it not when you see my toned legs and behind.
author: Beth R.

description:
Best stair workout in the city. For a good warmup, run flat along the Marina or around the Palace of Fine Arts... then, make your way up to the stairs and get ready for some serious pain. Right when you think you're near the top - here come another set of stairs!
Minus one star because I have to trek to the Marina to get there (I very much dislike having to drive to a workout).
author: Anika K.

description:
I hate these steps...I love these steps...They kill me. 
What a great workout...I can't say I ran up the entire way real fast by any means but I felt it all the way. I was there with a small group of Boot Campers and there was a much, much larger group of Bay Area Boot Campers there as well. I haven't gone there on my own but today might be the day....
author: Mellie D.

description: Ahhh, the Lyon Steps. These are built for all fitness levels to the leisure tourist. With amazing views, fresh air and variation in stair layout, they have the right mix of everything you need to keep from feeling bored and mundane. These stairs have seen me through some times in my life. Put the earphones in and get to climbing. I promise you will feel better about whatever is going on in your life. Big Smiles!!!
author: Adrian P.

description:
Oh no.  am I really writing a review about how I "used to" be in good enough shape to race up the Lyon steps?  I swore I'd never get here!

Runners take note - this is the spot.  Whether you're brave enough to take a few laps up and down the stairs or you just want to incorporate it into an incredible Presidio and/or marina run, this is a great and gorgeous little kick in the ass that can't help but make you think, "It doesn't get better than this."
author: Jenny S.

description:
It was a sunday morning. 
We have 3 weeks till our half marathon.  Lets finish w/ the Lyons steps we say to each other.  I thought the hills were bad, but these steps kicked my ass.  Lets "jog" it we say to each other.  I thought it would never end.  When would this stop???  Finally got to the top after feeling like we're going to pass out.  But it was worth the run! The endorphins made the view look soo much nicer!  Beautiful view at the top on a clear and sunny day!
author: Amelia S.

description:
when we were high school kids, my sunday school friend LH would drive me here with much excitement to show me her "dream house."  it turned out to be the house at the top of the lyon street steps.  we would sit in the dark in her car and wonder what those fancy people were doing behind the glowing curtains.  on our way home we would contemplate complex schemes to take over the world and earn the millions to purchase our dream real estate.

flash forward 10+ years later, and these steps are actually in my neighborhood.  sometimes i accidentally (or do i?) take a detour from the marina and end up back where i started, to the romantic dreams of making it big as an immigrant kid in the US.  

but i'm not a kid anymore.  and i now live a few blocks away.  i must be getting warmer....

an amazing place to sit and dream.
author: Josie M.

description:
as a part of my latest "get fit quick" scheme, i've incorporated the lyon street steps into my weekly routine.

whenever i commit to getting my ass in shape (...literally) i make sure to frequent Dailey Method, and now will absolutely add the lyon street steps

bring your ipod if you run them alone, or do what i did the first time and bring a friend you want to catch up with. went just before dusk so it wasn't crowded at all. absolutely gorgeous view of the marina from the top, and tons of "one day i'll live in a pac heights mansion" houses to drool over
author: Brianna H.

description:
I decided to run the stair cases at 10pm tonight! Never doing that again.. I was halfway up the first set of stairs when I saw a dark figure sitting on the bottom step. I was pretty frightened. It was a homeless man. I quickly said hi and bolted up the stairs never to look back. Scared the living daylights out of me. At least I hit my target heart rate.  :( 

Anywho... I finished my workout on the second bigger set of stairs where there was a security guard present. :) 

My quads will be hurting tomorrow. :(
author: Simon S.

description:
The Lyon Street Steps are absolutely worth a try for everyone enjoying some exercise. Why spend 90 dollar a month on a gym when you can exhaust yourself running up and down these steps, and even better; enjoy the view after all your effort? Make sure to pick a good time (late afternoon for me) to avoid too much people on the stairs.

I usually start at the beginning of Lyon Street down at the Palace of Fine Arts, a 2000 feet run up a steep hill... and just when you're already getting tired, the Lyon Street Steps show up. The first set of steps are very steep and narrow, so make sure to pick your moment since is difficult to pass people on your way up. After you crossed the terrace another set of steps show up, which are a little wider and less steep. Enjoy the view (especially before dawn when the lights are getting on) and go down to re-climb the steps... over and over.
author: Frank d.

description: A-MAZING! Just started running these steps and I love them (not so much when I'm actually on them :) Can't believe I live in Pac Heights and it took me 3 months to discover them, shame on me! Great workout, amazing view, and people seem to be totally respectful of other folks working out, no matter what their speed. Goodtimes
author: Jen P.

description: My favorite place to climb stairs. I am fortunate enough to live about 6 blocks away, and even though I'm not a fan of the marina workout crowd, I do love adding these steps in when I go over the hill on a run to the bridge. If I'm looking for a quick workout, I do a few rounds up the steps and call it a day. But most of the time I add a couple of rounds in at the end of my long runs when my legs are like jello and the burn really kicks in. I avoid this place when it's sunny. The crowds can be obnoxious, so I usually come here at dusk or with a light in the evening. Less crowds and less tourists snapping pictures of you when you make it to the top and look like death.
author: Courtney s.

description:
i recently added this to my daily regimen.  its walkable from my house and although i'm severely asthmatic and steps are my nemesis, i will overcome this in time.  or have a heart attack - death is chasing me these days as you may or may not recognize:(

also, if i bring you here to make out, it means that i really really like you.
author: Karen K.

description: I think everyone else has said it all, but truly, there is nothing like completing a tough workout on these stairs on a gorgeous SF day.
author: Amy M.

description: Man, I'm ready for 470 calories of thirst quenching Jamba Juice after sweating these stairs.  I'm not Lyon.
author: Teddy B.

description:
amazing workout. These steps will make you feel good about yourself once you hike and and down them. I like to end a long presidio perimeter walk with the steps.  Lots of people come here for a workout as well as those who just want to take a look at the stairs. 
This is a good place to bring guests to show them massive amounts of steps and hills.  Have them hike up it for a good time.
author: Valerie S.

description:
[disclamer: so this is TECHNICALLY my 100th SF review, except i cheated because i realized it AFTER i wrote my review .. the one after this one is what i had for lunch today, and it's extremely worth it, if you work in the FiDi, IMHO).

***

I LOVE/HATE this place with a passion...

Ok, being the health nut I'm trying to be, I've pretty much explored SF (walking, that is), and the farthest I walked from Chestnut/Fillmore was all the way to Howard/Embarcadero where the Cupid's Arrow is at, or wait, was the Golden Gate farther? No clue. 

Now, that was NOTHING compared to the steps of Lyon. 

Sheesh! 

Talk about a true, heart pumping workout... 

FO SHEEEEEEEEEEZ, my fwends... 

there are a total of 269 steps going ONE way. LoL... yes, i've counted ... LOL, i kno i have nothing better else to do, and honestly, it took prolly 3 attempts to finally get that #, only because everytime i was out of breath, i'd be too caught up catching my breath OR gettin distracted w/my music on my ipod, and honestly, it helped me make it through without stopping ... 

Man, there is NO NEED FOR A GYM MEMBERSHIP... 

I swear! 

This place is beautiful, tough, and FREE... 

it is what it is. 

I have to say my fave part is strolling through the Presidio Trail and cutting through Lombard towards Chestnut to go home, just make a quick right from the top of the stairs. Idk if I can make it here daily, my legs are KILLING me...  i'm impressed that i did make an attempt to come here couple times a  week though ... 

my next challenge? 

prolly to wake up at the break of dawn and work it..
author: Jennifer S.

description: Located right by the pedestrian gate leading to/from the Presidio, stop to catch the breathtaking view from the top, middle, or base of the Lyon Street Steps.  For those not in top shape like myself, it can be intimidating to see these fit creatures moving swiftly up and down the steps with ease.  Just one set of stairs sets my quads on fire.
author: Marsha Z.

description: Second best way to get your morning workout - but watch out for the early morn snails on the steps, please. They didn't do nuttin' to you....poor little guys.
author: Jennifer B.

description: What a beautiful view.  Probably one of my favorite places to come and reflect over why I ever moved to San Francisco.  The the view at these  steps is akin to heaven (but can be hell when you have to walk up them).
author: Joanna S.

description: Best place to run your butt off (literally) while looking at gorgeous bizillion dollar mansions on the way up, and views of the bay on the way back down. Just watch it on the way down - some are a bit narrow, some are a bit steep. Use that handrail!
author: Kelly C.

description: This is probably a great place to break up with somebody. It's so lush and offers an amazing view. Take the hike up the steps, have a sit, break it to them gently and marvel at the world that is laid before you. Nothing seems sad when you are here.
author: Colleen B.

description: Love running up and down these. Bonus: Because there is a security guard protecting Diane Feinstein's house every night, the stairs are super safe to run during any time of the day!
author: Lizzie L.

description: I tried the stairs for the first time yesterday. I heard that they were tough but the view made it worth it. Lyon Street Steps on the way up are the stairs to HELL but when you get to the top and turn around they become the stairs from HEAVEN. What an amazing VIEW! It's almost like each time you get to the top God gives you a little treat for working so hard . . . .the amazing blue water from the bay, gorgeous homes in Cow Hollow, WOW!
author: Heather A.

description: Great place to take the folks from out of town, especially in spring when all the flowers are in bloom.  No need to run up and down the stairs -- just take your time and enjoy.
author: Andi T.

description:
i was in a REEEEEALY foul mood at the end of the day a few weeks ago.  a steer-clear-of-this-bitch kind of mood.  my options for dealing with this state of affairs were: working out (most healthy/productive); breaking something (not really my style); drinking heavily (definitely my style, but not really in my best interest).  

i took the high road, literally, and hit the lyon street stairs.  four or five times up and down these calf-burners, with the view of the entire bay threatening to distract me and send me tumbling down (which would NOT have improved my mood), and i was back to my normal bright and sunny disposition.  thank you lyon street stairs!
author: Kirsten F.

description: Awesome and extremely intense stairs for running.  Great work out.  Plus beautiful surroundings.  Highly recommended.
author: Lauren M.

description: I started doing these this month during my run, but this week, it started raining so I quit.  It's a great hidden place to do some cardio/circuit training and there are usually others going up and down the steps so you have some company in the pain. It can get crowded, and you're too busy trying to huff and puff up the steps to really enjoy the view.
author: James B.

description: One of the most incredible views of the city...I ran the stairs a couple times after taking a long break from running.  I hobbled around for about 4 days after that.  It's so much better than a stairmaster though because when you make it to the top, you get the great view of the Marina and you feel like Rocky.
author: Rosie F.

description: Just take a bus/car/taxi to the top. Then marvel at the view, take a few pictures, and hop on another bus/car/taxi to take you back down. That's my lazy-ass, no-need-to-get-your-heart-rate-up way of seeing one of the most amazing views in SF. Fo sheeez.
author: Ali L.

description: My new favorite workout destination from my house!  I love the views and the feeling is so great when you finally make it to the top!  It's so much easier going down.  Then you gotta decide, should I go up again?  Great workout!
author: Britt B.

description: Luv to run up and down these things...its MUCH easier if you skip steps...AND, don't look down!!!
author: Peter S.

description: nice view from the top.  it's also pretty close to the exploratorium and the palace of the fine arts so take a few extra minutes to visit the steps.   walk in the opposite direction from the palace on lyon street until you reach green street.  there's usually no tourists, just a few stairclimbers, but watch your step!
author: Immer E.

description: I use to live near here and ran 1/4 of the way.  My house was 1 block away.  I wish my great grandparents were rich I owned one of these houses.  Back in the 1940s you could buy one of the babies for a cool $900,000.  But they were just a bunch of fatties and ate their money away.
author: Fatty A.

description: This is my favorite part of San Francisco! It has the best homes and views anywhere. What's so nice about this is you can get an excellent workout in a first class location for free. I have seen newlyweds step out of their limo to get photographs of themselves at this location. This is part of what makes San Francisco so special.
author: David P.

description:
on a sunny day,

that rare aurora Borealis of San Francisco, this place sparks magic to ones eye.

but its a beautiful place.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: OK, I agree, the steps are beautiful blah blah blah.  But nobody tells you how extremely hard they are to run.  I have only been able to max out at 3 times up and down the steps, and when I was done I had to pass out for an hour.  Also, nobody tells you how dangerous they are.  There is so much to look at (beautiful views, cute yuppies, fancy houses, etc.) that you can easily slip and hurt yourself, especially on the bottom steps. However, if you concentrate on just running the steps this is a great outdoor workout. And when you are all done and passed out on the sidewalk you will have beautiful things to look at.
author: Jake A.

description: Screw you, Stairmaster! I can work 10 times harder by going to Lyon St., plus take in some awesome views of SF. I am officially addicted. And also a little too cocky, as I began my first experience at these steps by sprinting up the lower, steeper set....not a good idea. I'll be feeling that for a while!
author: Beth T.

description: After running up these steps (best to come after running at Crissy field, it's killer,... run from Crissy by the bay, then uphill to the stairs, then the stairs! awesome) everything is starry.  Five stars, ten, 20, they keep spinning too.  Fireworks!
author: Today Y.

description: What a beautiful destination for a grueling workout.  If you have that big race or just want to burn a few extra calories route your jog through this glorious set of stairs that bridges Cow Hollow to Pac Heights.   Great people watching and the fresh air of the Presidio.  One of SF's simple treasures for sure.
author: Todd J.

description: For the health conscious in SF . . . The Lyon Street steps are a must.
author: M S.

description: I feel like collapsing....yet I still gave these 288 steps 5 stars.  How curious!  I think it has to do with the fact that I ran up and down both sets (sometimes both at once) 5 or 6 times this morning (I lost all conciousness   of anything around me around the 4th time up) during boot camp, and when I'm in my bikini on vacation at the end of the month, I'm going to thank these steps over and over again!    I'll take the sweeping views, the beautiful garden between lower and upper steps, and overall feeling that in one visit I'm significantly in better shape than I was before over going to the gym ANY DAY!  This wasn't my first trip, it certainly won't be my last!
author: Kate C.

description: i'm a native of SF.  I've lived my entire life here, until i was 18.  I'm in my early 30s now, and have only now been introduced to  the Lyon st. steps! Thanks, Jacey!! i didn't think it would be that hard of a workout, but when i got home, i noticed my legs were feeling wobbly.  hehe.
author: joseph k.

description: A must see in San Francisco. The stairs climb up to the Pacific Heights mansions on the east edge of the Presideo. If you've got the energy, put on your running shoes and hoof it up and down the stairs for a good workout. You'll be rewarded at the top by a great view of the bay and the Palace of Fine Arts.
author: Dave L.

description: Word of advice to all.   If you are going to make a bet with someone... make the stakes good old fashion "money" and not running these steps 5 times.  Great workout but damn hard.
author: Tom C.

description: You do have to pay attention, but that's what makes it such an experience. You're not just in pain, you're looking out over some of the most gorgeous views around, you're jealous of the people who live in that mansion, you're proud of yourself for getting up the steps, you're breathing this fresh Presidio air... And the awesome thing is that if you're just starting you can run right into the Presidio and go to Crissy Field... but if you're wrapping up you can walk right over to Union street and get a smoothie and relax... Its one of those little spots that feels like a great discovery.
author: ruth k.

description: I was in awe of this chick who was powering up the 2 inclines at the steeper-lower half of the stairs. She's my hero.
author: Michelle C.

description: One of the most beautiful spots to workout outside in SF.  The stairs are mesmerizingly challenging, but at least you're outside taking in the fresh air vs sweating away in the smelly gym.
author: Heather C.

description: Great for both brisk walk up and down the stairs or also for intense workout. Wondeful flight of steps with great views, not sure if the owners of those houses nearby do mind the number of people that come here to use the stairs, oh well....kinda the same situation with Lombard - crooked st...I wonder if anybody lives in those houses...they look too model-like/too perfect! :)
author: Yan M.

description: My lungs were burning and my thighs were shaking but damn -- exercise has never been so scenic!
author: Elizabeth H.

description: Just when I think my run is getting a little too flat for San Francisco...sha-BAM! I hit the steps and let it rip!
author: Diane S.

description: This is a great workout - buns of steel baby. It's also gorgeous, scenic and in a high class neighborhood. love the little gardens. My question: who lives in those houses on the stairs - especially the one with the guard?
author: melissa h.

description: I am beginning to wonder how many times I've climbed up you.  Mostly I love you once I am at the top.  But ever since Diane F move in and she re-did her ront yard, the steps are even more beautiful to go up.  The pretty landscape helps with distracting me from my huffing and puffing.
author: e w.

description: used to live close by.  great workout site, gets crouwed on the weekend and walkers get in the way
author: Bruce B.

description:
LOVE THEM!!!! i've been going to the steps since i was in middle school.  my favorite is taking people to them and racing them up the stairs after they're tired from walking all the way down.  
A beautiful view of the exploratorium and I have never seen more than 4 or 5 people walking up or down them. I've also never seen tourists around, which makes me appreciate San Francisco's secrets even more. 
(i was once told that robin williams home is next door to them, i wonder if its true)
author: Jennie M.

description: After all of this yelping, I needed a few trips up the steps to burn off those extra calories. For extra amusement, come here with your out of shape friends, and watch them huff and puff their way up.
author: Dana L.

description: This definitely beats stairs-masters.  I like to take out-of-towners here for the nice scenary.
author: Bessie T.

description: What an awsome find.  I came here with some friends about a year ago and fell in love.  It is a perfect place to enjoy a picturesque view of the bay and/or a great work out surrounded by multi-million dollar homes.  I certainly plan to make full use of the cities best free stair climber when the days grow longer.  This is also a great place for a picnic or other things a little more naughty than nice.
author: Brandon C.

description:
